PETITION.TITLE: Uranium
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled the petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That the export of uranium extends the nuclear cycle which fuels the development of nuclear weapons;
That no satisfactory means of dealing with nuclear waste has yet been devised;
That the mining and exporting of Australian uranium contributes to the nuclear fuel cycle.
Your Petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Government:
To withdraw from any treaty or agreement with Indonesia which will lead to the export of uranium to that country;
To foster research and development of safe and sustainable energy generation technologies in Australia and Indonesia;
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Higher Education Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

The petition of the undersigned demand the Australian Government honour its commitment to the Higher Education sector as stated in the Liberal and National Parties' Higher Education Policy (February 1996).
We demand the Australian Government honour its promises to:

PARA.TAB: maintain Austudy and Abstudy with benefits at real levels
maintain levels of funding to universities in terms of operating grants
maintain the Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS)
ensure no compulsory up‐front fees for undergraduate places
ensure no cuts in university places.

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners ask that the Senate oppose any intention by an Australian Government to introduce student fees, increase HECS repayments, abolish Austudy or Abstudy, or cut funding for university places.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
PETITION.PARA: This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate your petitioners' appreciation of the vital role the ABC plays in the development of Australian culture and in the provision of quality news and information services, including in regional Australia.
Proposed alterations to the ABC charter and cuts to its funding and staff levels will have an extremely adverse effect on the ABC's performance of these roles.

Your petitioners express their grave concern that the Government proposes to break its unequivocal election promise to maintain current levels of ABC funding and proposes to redefine the ABC's role so that it has a narrower focus and is more politically acceptable to the Howard Government.

Your petitioners request that the Senate ensures the current ABC charter, funding and staffing levels are maintained so that the ABC retains its independence and viability as an effective national broadcaster.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the certain residents of the State of New South Wales draws to the attention of the Senate that:
1. The Coalition's decision to means test the Childcare Cash Rebate discriminates against working parents and is a breach of a pre‐election promise, where the Coalition's policy clearly stated
`We are committed to maintaining a non means tested Childcare Cash Rebate',

2. The Coalition's decision to abolish operational subsidies for community based long day care centres will result in these centres having to charge higher fees, which will again discriminate against working parents; and

3. The Coalition's changes to the income test for Childcare Assistance will mean that the majority of parents pay far more in increased child care costs than provided through the Family Tax Initiative.
Your petitioners request that the Senate:
1. exert pressure on members of the Coalition to reverse the outcomes of the `1996 Federal Budget in relation to child care
2. hold members of the Coalition to their pre‐election commitments to retain the former system of child care; and
3. vote against legislation given effect to these changes which are to the detriment of Australian families.

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that any reform to Australia's system of industrial relations should recognise the special needs of employees to be protected from disadvantage, exploitation and discrimination in the workplace.

We the petitioners oppose the Coalition policies which represent a fundamentally anti‐worker regime and we call upon the Senate to provide an effective check and balance to the Coalition's legislative program by rejecting such a program and ensuring that:
1. The existing powers of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission (AIRC) be maintained to provide for an effective independent umpire overseeing awards and workplace bargaining processes.

2. The proposed system of Australian Workplace Agreements (AWAs) should be subject to the same system of approval required for the approval of certified agreements (through enterprise bargaining). Specifically, an AWA should not come into effect unless it is approved by the AIRC.

3. The approval of agreements contained in the legislation should be public and open to scrutiny. There should be provision for the involvement of parties who have a material concern relating to the approval of an agreement, including unions seeking to maintain the no disadvantage guarantees.
4. Paid rates awards be preserved and capable of adjustment, as is currently the case in the legislation.
5. The AIRC's powers to arbitrate and make awards must be preserved in the existing form and not be restricted to a stripped back set of minimum or core conditions.
6. The legislation should encourage the processes of collective bargaining and ensure that a certified agreement within its term of operation cannot be over‐ridden by a subsequent AWA.
7. The secondary boycott provisions should be preserved in their existing form.

8. The powers and responsibility of the AIRC to ensure the principle of equal pay for work of equal value should be preserved in its existing form. We oppose any attempt by the Coalition to restrict the AIRC from dealing with overaward gender based pay equity issues.
9. A `fair go all round' for unfair dismissal so that all workers currently able to access these remedies are able to do so in a fair manner, at no cost.
10. Workers under state industrial regulations maintain their rights to access the federal awards system in its current form.
Your petitioners therefore urge the Senate to reject the above proposed reforms to the area of industrial relations.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee's concerns with these instruments include possible prejudicial retrospectivity, breaches of personal rights and drafting deficiencies. I also seek leave to make a short statement on scrutiny by the committee of instruments made under the Native Title Act.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, on 27 June 1996 I reported on action by the Regulations and Ordinances Committee in respect of certain instruments made under the Native Title Act. The committee had ascertained that an important legislative determination made on Christmas Eve 1993, the very day that the Native Title Act received royal assent, was never tabled and so ceased to have effect 15 sitting days later. The committee was alerted to the failure to table when a subsequent determination, made some two years later, purported to amend the earlier determination. After the committee notified the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet of the, by now, more than two years invalidity, a fresh determination was made, gazetted and tabled, all on the same day. That fresh determination, however, could legally only operate from that date and could not validate any action taken in putative reliance on the earlier determination. Any such action taken during that period of more than two years was, of course, totally void.

SPEECH.PARA: When I reported to the Senate earlier, I advised that the committee would continue to inquire into this matter. The committee then wrote to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron) about the practical effects of the invalidity and of the steps proposed to remedy the situation. We have now received the minister's reply, which illustrates the need to comply with the statutory requirements for tabling delegated legislation.

The invalid determination provided for mandatory action in specified circumstances by the Commonwealth minister, the Commonwealth itself, the states and territories and the native title registrar. One of these circumstances was notification by governments of their intention to do a future act, such as grant a mining lease. In response to the committee's inquiry, the minister advised that there may have been thousands of these actions, all of which were totally invalid. Another circumstance concerned applications for determinations of native title, in respect of which the minister advised the committee that there were hundreds of invalid actions. Another aspect of the invalidity related to actions by state and territory agencies, the minister advising the committee that there was little likelihood that the range and extent of these could easily, if ever, be ascertained. This result is scarcely a flattering picture of Commonwealth public administration, with thousands of invalid actions, some of which date back more than two years.

PARA.BREAK: The minister also advised the committee that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) had asked the state and territory governments for their preferred option to correct the situation. As a result of these consultations, the proposed amendments provided for by the Native Title Amendment Bill 1996 would include a provision to validate retrospectivity of all of these thousands of actions. The committee in this case will not oppose such amendments, if only because to do otherwise would result in the considerable financial expenditure in this area over the last two years being wasted, and because of the waste of time if the whole process had to start again. Moreover, it would adversely affect thousands of people who had acted in the honestly held but incorrect belief that their actions were valid. The committee nonetheless has substantial reservations about the Commonwealth legislation providing for prejudicial retrospectivity. The minister did not expressly advise that the retrospectivity would be prejudicial but, if it was not prejudi cial, the problem could be corrected by delegated legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the Acts Interpretation Act legislative instruments may operate retrospectively only if nobody apart from the Commonwealth is adversely affected. The final outcome, therefore, is that thousands of ineffective actions will be validated years later by prejudicially retrospective provisions of a Commonwealth act. This is an unfortunate result but one which, as I say, cannot be avoided without much time and money being wasted. The committee was assisted in this matter by the prompt actions of the Prime Minister and the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Senator Herron, for which the committee is grateful.

Winston Churchill is said to have remarked that when he was told that a battleship was being launched he did not ask whether it had a bottom. In the present case, on behalf of the Senate, the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances asked whether the native title battleship had a bottom. In this case, it did not.

Leave granted.
The Broadcasting Services Amendment Bill 1996 seeks to amend the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 to facilitate a commitment made by the government in its pre‐election policy statements.

The bill would amend the Broadcasting Services Act to ensure that the minister's power to direct the ABA to conduct investigations can extend to an investigation of future regulatory arrangements and policy directions in respect of on‐line services. This is an interim measure, pending government consideration of a comprehensive regulatory framework for on‐line services.

The current directions power in section 171 of the act provides some scope for the ABA to be directed to investigate the regulation of matters that the act does not cover. However, generally speaking, such investigations must be incidental to the operation or administration of the current act. In relation to services not covered by the act, such as on‐line services, this limits the role of the ABA to making recommendations about provisions that the act should make for those services, as it did in its June 1996 report Investigation into the content of on‐line services. The act does not authorise a broader ABA investigation, in consultation with industry, into matters that might be included in codes of practice as part of a future regulatory regime.

Consistent with its election policy commitment, Australia On‐line, the government proposes to introduce a regulatory framework for the on‐line industry incorporating codes of practice, supervised by the ABA. The proposed new directions power will allow the minister to direct the ABA to investigate suitable codes of practice, pending the development of legislation implementing the government's policy.

The proposed new section 171 will allow the minister to direct the ABA in writing to investigate any matter in respect of which the parliament is able to make laws under the "postal, telegraphic and other like services" power in paragraph 51 (v) of the Constitution. In particular, the minister will be able to direct the ABA to investigate any matter relating to the future regulation or operation of telecommunications services, including on‐line services.

The provisions in the bill have been drafted broadly to give the minister the flexibility to issue a range of investigation directions to the ABA that are consistent with evolving government policy on the future regulation of on‐line services.
I table an explanatory memorandum and commend the bill to the Senate.
Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of this bill be adjourned until the first day of sitting in the Autumn sittings, in accordance with the order agreed to on 29 November 1994.

If we firstly go to the Guide to key elements of ministerial responsibility which was published in April this year by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), there are two key elements to the document. The first element I want to refer to is on page 10, and it says:

Ministers must be honest in their public dealings and should not intentionally mislead the parliament or the public. Any misconception caused inadvertently should be corrected at the earliest opportunity. Ministers are required to divest themselves of all shares and similar interests in any company or business involved in the area of their portfolio responsibilities. The transfer of interests to a family member or to a nominee or a trust is not an acceptable form of divestment.

This code of ministerial responsibility was set down by the Prime Minister shortly after the election. It is now seven months since the election and just over six months since Senator Short became Assistant Treasurer and Senator Gibson became Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer.

These two senators are the persons responsible on behalf of the Liberal government for handling economic matters in this chamber, but their duties obviously extend far beyond that. I would like to refer to a press release from the Treasurer that outlines the responsibilities of both the Assistant Treasurer and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer. They have a highly detailed knowledge of what goes on in relation to economic decision making in respect of the Liberal government, and obviously in respect of the budget.

In respect of the shareholdings involving banks—in Senator Short's case, the ANZ Bank; in Senator Gibson's case, the National Australia Bank and the Bank of Melbourne—there is no doubt that there is a direct conflict of interest in those areas. But I submit to the Senate that, if we look at the shareholdings of both senators, and they are very wide‐ranging shareholdings, it is not just banks we are talking about. If we look at Senator Short's shareholdings, BHP, CRA, CSR, Boral, Pasminco, Jennings Industries, Centroproperties, MIRVAC, AGL, Cornwall Resources, Valero Energy and Parkwick Pty Ltd are shares directly owned and directly controlled by the Assistant Treasurer. For Senator Short's information, he has not corrected his entry in the register of interests: Bridge Oil ceased to trade two years ago. If we look at Senator Gibson's shareholdings, he has shares in the Bank of Melbourne, the National Australia Bank—he has not said whether he is going to sell those shares; he has not said anything about that today in the Senate—Woolworths, CRA, AGL, Amcor, BHP, BTR, Boral, Brambles, CSR, F.H. Faulding, National Foods and Simsmetal.

I put it to the Senate that, in view of the duties and responsibilities of these two senators, there is a massive conflict of interest. There is a massive conflict of interest in them continuing to own and exercise authority over these shareholdings.

If we look at the interests of other senators, ministers and parliamentary secretaries in the register of senators' interests, no such conflict of interest exists that we can find in respect to any other ministers or parliamentary secretaries. Senator Parer, for example, had direct shareholdings in a mining company which he disposed of. He did the right thing, but not Senator Short and Senator Gibson. Senator Short has been caught out and today has admitted he has had to sell the shares in ANZ.

Senator Short is directly involved in policy development with respect to banking. Why weren't these shares sold six months ago when he became a minister? That is when they should have been sold. I submit to the Senate that all the other shareholdings should have been sold six months ago because we have a Prime Minister, Mr Howard, who makes a great virtue of honesty and integrity in government. We now have a new document of ministerial responsibility. What you have done as minister and as parliamentary secretary is directly defied the Prime Minister's instruction which is very clear in this area—you are required to divest yourselves of shares and similar interests in any company or business. You have failed to do so.

Your other ministerial and parliamentary secretary colleagues in this place have done so. Why haven't you? You are involved in direct decision making in respect of banking matters that affect the share price of ANZ. We will check the share price and see how well you have done as a consequence of announcing today that you are selling your ANZ shares. We will check that share price—six months too late!

On behalf of the Labor opposition, we highlight this issue in the Senate today. This is not the first mistake Senator Short has made in this place in the last six months. Senator Short cannot answer questions in question time; he cannot even answer questions from his own side. He has already had to apologise for misleading the Senate about sales tax legislation that arose from the Premiers Conference.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report of Employment, Education and Training Legislation Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Employment, Education and Training Legislation Committee on the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2), together with the submissions received by the committee and transcripts of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly to that report. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

Essentially, this bill provides for the repeal of sections 25A and 25B of the 1988 act. These sections enable the Commonwealth minister under the so-called SOS program, the student organisation support program, to provide funds for student organisations in states that have passed legislation relating to voluntary student unionism and prohibiting universities from levying compulsory student membership fees. The sections also enable the Commonwealth to recoup from the states the Commonwealth funds given to student unions. Over $14½ million of taxpayers' money has been redirected to student organisations under these arrangements by the previous Labor government.

The committee agrees that student associations are an important element of tertiary education experiences and, where these associations are valued by students, they will enjoy student support. For example, at the University of the Melbourne, since the Victorian government has enacted legislation on voluntary student unionism, 85 per cent of the student bodies are members of the student association. We note, however, that similar support is not forthcoming from students at the University of Western Australia.

In the committee's view, the matter of funding for student organisations is one that must be resolved between the universities themselves and their state governments. It is not appropriate for the Commonwealth to intervene where the states' jurisdictions over their universities are very clearly defined. The Commonwealth should not legislate to undermine or to prevent the states from exercising their properly constituted responsibilities for the universities. The SOS program is an example of this and should be removed from the Commonwealth statutes.

Another difficulty relating to the SOS program concerned the issue of ministerial discretion in determining the level of Commonwealth funds payable to student organisations under the SOS program. We have already seen the Victorian government take action in the courts against the Commonwealth, alleging that the funds approved by the Commonwealth minister for payment to certain student organisations were in excess of what was lawful under the federal legislation. The Victorian government was also concerned about the inadequacy of the consultative mechanisms between the Commonwealth and the state in determining the appropriate level of payment to these unions.

It seems, therefore, that the legislation under which the student organisation support program has operated is both problematic in principle and in its implementation. Not only does it intervene in an area of university operation which is the jurisdictional preserve of the state government, but the manner of its operation, in particular the way in which ministerial discretion is exercised, is substantially flawed. In the committee's view, sections 25A and 25B of the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 should be repealed. The committee recommends that the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1996 be passed without amendment. I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the motion to take note of the report and to draw the Senate's attention to the minority report presented on behalf of Labor and Democrat senators. The concerns we have with this proposal are that, essentially, it is motivated by a vindictive desire by this government to settle old scores which arose as a result of disputes within student unions a few years ago when the present Treasurer (Mr Costello) and senior members of the Liberal Party in Victoria got themselves involved in some disputes within student unions in that state. We have seen attitudes similar to that being expressed in Western Australia as well.

SPEECH.PARA: Labor senators take the view that student organisations are a crucial element of tertiary education and that they have a formal and statutory role to play in representing students of the universities on boards, in councils and in various other representative forums. To that extent, they should not be subject to unreasonable constraint in the exercise of their responsibilities or in the delivery of a wide range of services to students. We share the views of the executive director of the AVCC in that student organisations represent an important part of the educational experience and the learning culture, and all students should be able to and should participate in them, if they so desire.

We have seen that states, particularly reactionary governments in Victoria and Western Australia, have undertaken legislation to prevent universities from levying fees for student organisations. In so doing, in my view they are interfering with a university's right to decide on what conditions of enrolments in the institutions should be. They are deciding that on an unjust basis; that is, on the vindictive basis that because a few senior politicians in the Liberal Party lost out in political battles in the universities in their youth others should bear the cost of that. Those states that pull the funding plug are denying students access to a whole range of services.

Under state legislation, students are required to participate on a variety of university management committees and councils, yet universities are not allowed to levy fees to fund the student organisations, required by statute to represent students on those councils. The Commonwealth, in my judgement, has a responsibility to monitor the running of universities, especially given the huge funding commitment made by the Commonwealth to Australian universities.

Where situations arise which diminish the effectiveness or the quality of Australian universities, the Commonwealth has both a right and an obligation to seek to remedy those situations and to protect those student bodies from the vindictive actions of the Liberal Party. The threat to student organisations, including the possible demise of some, clearly diminishes the effectiveness and the quality of the education received by tertiary students. It puts at risk the standing of our universities amongst international students.

The Commonwealth has an obligation to provide protection and to ensure that such acts mitigate against the worst effects of such threats. That is why the Commonwealth SOS program was introduced. In my judgment it was right to do so and it is right now to maintain that provision within the act, to ensure that ministers have the capacity to provide assistance to student organisations so that there can be a proper functioning of student representation within our universities.

Sections 25A and 25B of the current act should remain. Even if this government does not have the courage to protect representative democracy in universities, the provisions should be available so the discretion is there for future ministers. That is the position that is clearly in the interests of the Commonwealth—to ensure that the quality and standing of our universities is maintained. This government is once again abrogating its responsibilities of national leadership to protect our universities and educational institutions.

Billions of taxpayer dollars are spent on universities in this country, funded by this parliament. Yet we have the legal fiction presented by petty state politicians that universities are state institutions. It is a legal fiction. The Commonwealth funds these institutions to an extraordinary degree. Public funding going into universities in this country is well in excess of 95 per cent and comes as a result of the actions of this parliament. It is an extraordinary proposition for this government to say that these are state institutions and that, as a consequence, the petty actions of provincial politicians should override and should allow this vindictive matter to be followed through.

TALK.START.PARA: —You were the chief adviser to a provincial politician.

—I have very deep involvements in state politics, but I say to Senator O'Chee that we do not have these sorts of actions taken by the Liberal Party in Victoria, by Mr Kroger's agents and Mr Costello's agents. There we have seen time and time again the failed actions undertaken by that government to try to intimidate and destroy representation and prevent people from freely expressing their views within that state. We have seen the Victorian government try time and time again to intimidate and prevent people from making a proper representation of points of view that happen to be different from those of the Kennett government. That is a position this parliament ought to make a stand on.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as I am concerned, the state governments are seeking to threaten a group of intelligent young people and are seeking to prevent them from enjoying the full range of the educational experience which is fundamental to university culture. They are trying to do it in such a way so as to ensure stifled debate and to prevent criticism emerging within those bodies.

It is not as though they are opposed to compulsion. It is not an issue about compulsion because a whole series of fees are levied upon students compulsorily. They do not object to those, but they are opposed to the involvement of student unions on the various campuses within the states of Victoria and Western Australia. They are opposed to political representation on those councils and the use of student funds to allow for the adequate and effective representations of students within those councils.

While the Victorian government has outlined compulsory membership of student associations, it has nonetheless provided for the collection by universities of compulsory fees for a range of 16 specified services. It seems that the principle of compulsion is not in itself the motive for the Victorian legislation but rather a specific instance—namely, the compulsion to join a student organisation as a condition of student enrolment. This instance is what we suggest is wrong with this provision. It goes to the very heart of whether or not this government has a commitment to robust democratic processes and why it is so reluctant to accept the criticism of the student bodies.

On the committee we heard the submissions from the University of Western Australia. The Western Australian Student Guild revealed that, quite clearly, the Western Australian university continues to be unable to levy compulsory amenity fees and, if the SOS program is withdrawn, the guild will become bankrupt and cease to function unless the university undertakes a rescue mission to support the essential student services. That move would entail a total financial commitment by the university of some $345,000 per annum.

Given the dramatic reductions in university operating grants, and the enormous cuts to higher education spending within the present budgetary arrangements, university resources of that magnitude are not available and will impact very severely upon the university's core functions. This is a matter which this parliament will have to consider in some detail. It will require considerable debate within this chamber to ensure that this government provides for the option in the future of allowing for effective student representation and of allowing for the funding, if necessary, through the SOS program to be maintained.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to delay the Senate any longer. The Senate has been delayed with a mindless and meaningless contribution from the other side. I just point out that there are many honourable senators on the other side of the chamber who joined their party because they opposed conscription. We on this side of the chamber oppose the conscription of the young people into student unions, which do not necessarily represent their views.

SPEECH.PARA: We also oppose the pilfering and rorting of money and the use of that money by some student activists in these student union organisations. That is what we are doing. It is not an attempt to stifle democracy, but it is an attempt to ensure that people who do not have a lot of money because they are students do not have their money wasted and compulsorily taken off them by student unions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on the same matter as a member of the Senate Employment, Education and Training Legislation Committee. I wish Senate O'Chee had provided those views to the committee because we had a very fulfilling and satisfying day of hearings, to which Senator Carr has already referred. Eight submissions were presented to us on that day and all the people, including those people representing various bureaucracies and departments in Western Australia and Victoria, expressed their regret that the Commonwealth or the state governments had found it necessary to interfere with the workings of student organisations.

SPEECH.PARA: I make the point that the term `union' is quite a misnomer in this case. It is something that was repeatedly referred to by witnesses on the day. It was also pointed out by the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee that student unions or student associations, as they are more appropriately called, have been around for centuries. They are a tradition of university and campus life, but they are not akin to trade unions and formal trade unions as such. In fact, student unions, guilds or associations—whatever we choose to call them—are more akin to a community, council or shire.

I have to take up a couple of points that have been raised in this debate. The point of choice is not about compulsion; it is about universal membership of a student organisation, as the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee agreed. The members of the Australian Vice‐Chancellors Committee are hardly a radical bunch of people, but they were amongst the strongest defenders of universal membership of student organisations.

They made the very clear point that, if a student chooses to enrol, the point of choice is at enrolment. It is at that point which they contribute fees to the student organisation which assists those people Senator O'Chee was referring to—those people who are perhaps from lower socioeconomic backgrounds who are more disadvantaged on campus, those people who benefit from the types of services and facilities that are provided by a student organisation.

The Australian Democrats believe, along with many of the witnesses—including the National Union of Students, the Council of Australian Postgraduate Associations and the Australian Vice‐Chancellors Committee—that student organisations are a vital part of campus life. They provide a range of services such as subsidised catering, recreation facilities, meeting rooms, sporting clubs, student newspapers or even representation, which seems to be the major sticking point.

That point seems to be why we have seen this attempt by certain state governments to emasculate these services that student unions and student organisations provide. The evidence presented to us showed that that was the case. In Western Australia, for example, we have guilds, as they are known there—student organisations—that are close to closing because they cannot afford to sustain and maintain their activities.
Senator Carr made the point that there may be a political motive to the actions of various state governments and, indeed, now the federal government.

TALK.START.PARA: —They're scared of students.

—Of course they are, and they should be scared of students because this government has launched an outright attack on students and higher education in this country—not just academics, not just general staff, not just administrators, but vice-chancellors as well as students and aspiring students in our community. Certainly, Senator Woodley, they are under attack. There is not just $623 million worth of operating grants being ripped out from under them but now the very vital campus services and representation that is provided has been taken away.
—That is not right.

—In deference to senators on the other side of the chamber, it is right. Perhaps if they care to read the report before us today they would be aware of exactly what is happening on campuses with student memberships as a result of the draconian measures that are being introduced, certainly in Western Australia. As many senators may know, Victorian legislation operates somewhat differently but still attacks those services that we are referring to.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to the political point, I found the comments of the Executive Director of the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee, Mr Frank Hambly, interesting. He said:

I probably should not say some of these things, but the reason this has happened is that some of the people who are now in parliament were students at the time when there were some unfortunate goings‐on in the national student body. They vowed that when they got into positions of influence they could do something about it, and they have.

I think the motive behind the higher education funding bill is quite a dubious one. It seeks to repeal sections 25A and 25B of the Higher Education Funding Act, which allow the Commonwealth to compensate those higher education institutions that have lost money as a result of state interference. It is an appropriate measure. It is one that the Democrats supported in 1992, 1993 and 1994 when the changes were made. We will continue to support it because, as I reiterate, we consider student organisations a vital part of campus life.

The overwhelming evidence provided in submissions, both in public hearings and in written form, was that all those organisations in the know—those organisations that work with or understand students and student organisations on a daily basis, as well as Australian vice-chancellors and administrators of universities—believed that it was regrettable that the government was considering this stance.

To that effect, the Australian Democrats and opposition senators have provided a dissenting report which recommends that the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1996 not be passed by the Senate, but also offers a constructive recommendation in the form of urging the federal government to develop a more coherent approach. DEBATE.TITLE: NATURAL HERITAGE TRUST OF AUSTRALIA BILL 1996

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report of Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts Legislation Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson, Sen Kay

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts Legislation Committee on the provisions of the Natural Heritage Trust of Australia Bill 1996, together with submissions and Hansard record of proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

After all the nonsense we have had in the chamber this morning, this report is a piece of good news. The committee, comprising members of the government and opposition—the Labor Party and a member of the Democrats—came to a unanimous decision. There was a minor disagreement on a major issue about whether the setting up of the Natural Heritage Trust should depend on the sale or otherwise of Telstra. The committee was of the opinion that, as there had been an inquiry on that and sufficient time and energy was spent on it, we ought to devote our time to the task before us, which was referred to us by the Senate on a motion by the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill).

I thank the members of the committee for their level of cooperation in coming to the report that we have. As I said, it was a unanimous report except for that one disagreement—albeit major. I also thank the Senate committee, who were under enormous stress at the time with the Telstra inquiry and called into the committee an additional staff member, Ms Robyn Hardy. I thank her for standing in in the way she did, for working with the committee secretariat so closely and, in fact, being the principal person involved with that inquiry. I thank her in particular and the secretariat for their involvement.

I also thank the people who made very thoughtful submissions. I must say that the committee found some of the evidence that we were given exciting. It would have been wonderful to share that with the rest of the Australian community. Some of the work that has been done, especially in rural areas of Australia, is nothing short of a miracle. It was world‐first stuff. It was an enormous privilege for us to hear from those people first‐hand. I commend the report to the Senate. I seek leave to incorporate my tabling statement in Hansard and to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—
I take pleasure in tabling the report of the inquiry by the Senate Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts Committee into the Natural Heritage Trust Bill 1996.

The bill was referred to my committee on 25 June 1996 by the Selection of Bills Committee. The reference was unusual in that it was referred by the Government for consideration rather than the Opposition. This is because the Government wished to obtain the views of the community, environment groups, landcare groups and other interested parties on the structure and objectives of the bill.
I feel that the committee has been very successful in obtaining a broad range of views and information which should assist the Government to further prepare this legislation.

I must say that the level of co-operation between the members of this committee and from interested groups has been remarkable. I have had the pleasure of meeting many talented and highly committed people determined to ensure that our environment is repaired, restored and maintained in a sustainable way for future generations.

It bodes well for the environment if we on the committee with our different political colours can get together and rationally discuss these vitally important issues and that there are people out there willing and able to achieve success—as one submission said—we can forget our petty turf fighting and get on with the job.

The committee certainly came to the view that the public is waiting for action from this bill. It has the potential to provide the vehicle for historic environmental action and with funding of the magnitude planned, care must be taken to get it right.

The purpose of the bill is to establish the Natural Heritage Trust of AustraIia Reserve. The main objective of the Reserve is to `repair and replenish Australia's natural capital infrastructure' and `money in the Reserve will be spent on the environment, sustainable agriculture and natural resources management.'
The initiatives covered by the bill include: Vegetation, rivers, Biodiversity, Landcare and Coasts and Clean Seas. A major part of the Trust centres on five capital projects:
. the National Vegetation Initiative
. the Murray-Darling 2001 Project
. the National Reserve System
. the National Land and Water Resources Audit
. and the Coasts and Clean Seas Initiative.
The major source of funds for the Reserve will be $1 billion from the partial privatisation of Telstra.

The committee could not agree on the source of funds. Opposition and Democrat Senators wanted the funding to come from Consolidated Revenue. Government Senators were of the opinion that given the level of National Debt that it was necessary to use an alternate source of funding. Recognising this fundamental disagreement, the committee decided to concentrate on the issues arising from the bill as drafted.
Therefore I believe the committee has come up with some very important and well considered views on the bill.

After receiving 99 submissions and 6 public hearings the committee concluded that a good deal of confusion and suspicion had been created by the use of the words `Board' and `Trust' in the bill, because of the way the public perceives the operation of private trusts. The committee therefore recommends that these either be changed or greater explanation be given in the bill of the parliamentary accountability arrangements and the roles of various ministers.

A good deal of the committee's time was taken up with consideration of advisory structures for the Board—ensuring representativeness without the creation of an unwieldy body or adding unnecessarily to the plethora of advisory committees already in place. After much consideration the committee recommends:
. that the two Ministers responsible for the Environment and Primary Industries Portfolios comprise the two-person Board;
that the Minister responsible for the Environment Portfolio be the Chair of that Board;
. that an Advisory Panel- consisting of about 8 experts be established to advise the Board and assess proposals for funding;
. as far as possible, and if appropriate, the existing specific purpose advisory councils should be retained and be a source of advice to the Panel if necessary;
. however, Departments should take this opportunity to examine these and other advisory structures, to streamline them and to ensure that duplication is avoided;

. that the Departments should, as a matter of urgency, streamline their administrative processes and co-ordinate with other funding organisations (such as State/Territory Departments) to simplify the funding/submission process and ensure that any system is flexible enough to address unforeseen changes in priorities and methods; and

. that the bill should included a reference to the type of advisory structures which will be put in place by the Departments and their roles and responsibilities and that separate regulations should contain the role of the Advisory Panel, the tenure of the members etc.

Many witnesses and submissions raised the issue of the various roles of the two responsible Departments—Environment, Sport and Territories and Primary Industries and Energy. Some were concerned that Primary Industries would dominate the Environment Portfolio, others saw advantage in finally ensuring a closer relationship. Whilst the Departments allayed many concerns by assuring the committee that the Environment Department would be the `lead' Department, the committee felt that the bill should explicitly state that the Minister responsible for the Environment Portfolio is Chair of the Board and that the Environment Department has primacy.

With respect to the scope of the bill's initiatives, the committee felt that there was potential for the bill to be inflexible to changes in priorities and needs if specific projects were outlined. Rather, it felt that the bill should include broad goals and objectives in the environmental areas Vegetation, Rivers, Biodiversity, Landcare, Coasts and Clean Seas and Atmospheric Issues. Further, the committee considered that the bill should be flexible enough to include, exotic pests, feral animals and weeds, international treaties on the environment and-education and training of the public landowners and users.

A number of submissions and witnesses drew the committee's attention to Australia's built heritage. The committee recommends that the Government address funding for Australia's Built Heritage as a matter of priority.

The committee was concerned about the intention to attract gifts and bequests of money to the Trust Fund. The concern was two-fold in that the funds would have to be kept separate from the Trust and managed in a highly visible way since a Government funding mechanism may not be appropriate for these sorts of funds. Further, a number of organisations felt that their funding requirements from the public may be diminished by such a call from a Government fund.

The committee also recommends that to ensure that funds spent by the Commonwealth are effective and not compromised by incompatible regulations and practices in the different States and Territories, that the bill include accountability arrangements for projects against measurable outcomes and that the Commonwealth work actively toward ensuring uniform or complementary legislation throughout Australia in the environment field.
Finally, the committee recommends a needs-based approach to funding rather than any arbitrary per capital or regional allocation system.
I commend this report to my colleagues in the Chamber with the hope that this bill will eventually be passed to the benefit of our environment and all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —The thrust of the legislation that the committee has been looking at is inherently important and acceptable to a great number of the Australian community. The point that Senator Patterson makes about disagreement over the link with the sale of Telstra totally overrides the thrust of this legislation itself. The government is predicating the good works that may come out of the proposed legislation on a totally different, unrelated matter—their wish to privatise Telstra. We cannot get away from that nexus that the government has made.

SPEECH.PARA: While ever it makes that nexus, it cannot claim that it is giving the environment the high consideration, the primary consideration, that the people of Australia repeatedly show they want through opinion polls and through their expression of concern for the environment in the going about of their day-to-day lives in this country.

Senator Patterson has commented on the near miraculous work being done in degraded areas of Australia by the good citizens. You have only to look at the Murray-Darling Basin to know what she is referring to. But at the same time, the same government is licensing the broadscale destruction of native forest ecosystems in the forested areas of Australia. So you have near miraculous repair work on the one hand but shameful, embarrassing environmental degradation being licensed by the government on the other hand.

There is an enormous inconsistency here. One cannot help but think that the government simply wants to ride on a false chimera of environmental goodness while it goes about the business of licensing the destruction of world heritage value forests, rainforests, national estate listed forests—forests which ought to be national park in New South Wales, Victoria, Western Australia, Tasmania and potentially now, because of the government's woodchip policy, Queensland. While this committee has been sitting and drawing up this report, the government at the same time has been giving the go-ahead to the Hinchinbrook tourist resort, the mega‐resort. This is totally inappropriate because of its impact on two World Heritage areas in central Queensland—namely, the Wet Tropics World Heritage area, and the Great Barrier Reef World Heritage area.

Just yesterday on the eve of this report being brought into this place, we received news that the Minister for the Environment, Senator Hill, who is unfortunately not here at the moment, had been dictated to by Mr Williams, the man behind that resort, and had gone to water. Here we have the country's chief environmentalist who, as I have said, is not present in the chamber, simply being dictated to, taking his queue from a mega‐developer whose record on the environment is abhorrent; whose record, by the way, for respecting other people's points of view is abhorrent; and whose ability in endeavouring to quash other people's points I view is, I think, odious.

Yet we have that particular minister bringing forward this legislation trying to take kudos to cover up the fact that, beyond Hinchinbrook and forests, the government is also into a record expansion in uranium mining. It has legislation to come before this place to override Aboriginal sentiments on whether or not mines should go ahead on Aboriginal lands—and we know the Aboriginal people of this country have an extraordinary and unique record with their relationship to the environment and to the protection of the land.

Everything is going negative, as far as the environment is concerned in this country, under this government, at a rate we have not seen in recent decades. This is a government of environmental villainy; it is a government of environmental destruction. It puts the environment way down the list. All it is interested in is the quick dollar. The mega‐developments get the nod. But the environment gets treated as some sort of patsy when this sort of legislation can be reported upon and a member of government can stand up and talk about near miraculous repair efforts. We will need more than miracles further down the line to repair the damage that is being done by this government.

It will cost future generations of Australians billions of dollars in trying to undo the damage being done to the forest environment, the wild environments around this country, the coastal environments—even the atmosphere we breathe in. This government is now notorious around the world for being at the back of the pack when it comes to trying to implement global measures to prevent the greenhouse gas phenomenon which is leading to global warming and to multi‐trillion dollar expenses, as action—which will be too late next century—is taken to try to prevent the world from getting into even greater economic, environmental and social disruption as a result of the impact of our carelessness. At this end of the 20th century you would expect a government, representing the people of Australia with their enormous environmental awareness, to be leading the world instead of coming from behind.

PARA.BREAK: The tragedy of this report is not what is in the report itself; it is what is behind it: the government treating the environment just as a patsy; the government paying lip-service to it; the government saying, `Yes, we'll do something about the environment, we'll give some funding to it'—and it is very modest funding at that—`provided we can sell off telecommunications in this country, provided we can sell off Telstra,' which is an entirely unrelated, unhitched subject to the environment. But what the government says is, `We are doctrinaire about selling off public utilities to the point that the environment has to take second string to that approach we have, which is that we want to put everything across to the private sector and divest ourselves of even the meagre powers that governments have these days in being able to try to rein in material ism and the impact it is having on the environment.'

SPEECH.PARA: It is not only the report itself that the Senate is being delivered today. It is also the political mischief behind that report of which we ought to be taking note.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present report No. 346 entitled Guarding the independence of the Auditor-General . I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

Prior to the 1996 election, the Hon. John Howard, now Prime Minister, gave a commitment to the Australian people to establish a completely independent Auditor-General who would be an officer of the parliament as part of a broader strategy to restore authority, dignity and meaning to the parliamentary institutions. The existence of a strong and independent Auditor-General is absolutely fundamental for the effectiveness of parliament itself and its scrutiny of the executive government. Indeed, former Auditor-General John Taylor told the Joint Committee of Public Accounts in 1994 that he considered the question, `Who will control the Auditor-General?', to be one of the great battles between the parliament and the executive. It is a battle which has a long history.

In 1902 the first Auditor‐General in his first report to the parliament stated that his office was inadequately resourced for the discharge of his audit functions. The Joint Committee of Public Accounts has reported to the parliament twice in the last decade on the desirability of strengthening the relationship between the parliament and the Auditor‐General.

In report No. 296, which was tabled in 1989, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, which also then I was a member of, informed the parliament that the Australian Audit Office, as it then was, was in a state of crisis, that it was under‐resourced and that a lot of problems stemmed from parliamentary complacency. The Joint Committee of Public Accounts also reported that there was confusion about whether the executive or the parliament was responsible for the Auditor‐General, with the result that the office was neglected by both.

In report No. 331, tabled in 1994, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts made a series of recommendations to amend the Auditor‐General Bill 1994 to enhance the functional independence of the Auditor‐General from the executive and to provide for greater parliamentary involvement in the performance of the audit function. Today, seven years on from the original JCPA report, the question of where the Auditor‐General fits in the framework of government still generates heated debate, as the committee discovered during its inquiry. However, the incumbent Auditor‐General, Mr Pat Barrett, was in no doubt that he considered parliament to be his employer.

In this report, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts has recommended that in the Auditor‐General Bill the Auditor‐General be declared an `independent officer of the parliament'. The title encapsulates the role and status of the office of the Auditor‐General. The Auditor‐General performs a function that is essential to parliamentary scrutiny but which the parliament itself has neither the technical expertise nor the resources to perform.

While acknowledging that debate about the status of the Auditor‐General is essentially about symbolism, we believe that symbolism is important. To a very large degree, the way in which the position of the Auditor‐General is described influences public perceptions of the role and the significance of the office. It is important to note, however, that in the legislative model proposed by the JCPA the Auditor‐General would not be subject to direction by the parliament. I think the Clerk of the Senate would be pleased to note that.

The Joint Committee of Public Accounts has recommended that the guarantee of the Auditor‐General's audit independence be enshrined in the Auditor‐General Bill, putting it beyond doubt that the Auditor‐General has complete discretion in determining the audit program of the Australian National Audit Office and in deciding the manner in which audits shall be conducted.

The Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey), in referring this matter to the JCPA for inquiry, drew the committee's attention to concerns that the appointment of the Auditor‐General as an officer of the parliament could damage the independence of that office. The committee has reviewed the legal opinions obtained by the Australian National Audit Office on this issue. The committee is concerned that these legal opinions were obtained in a vacuum of policy advice about the intentions or will of the government and the parliament in appointing the Auditor‐General as an officer of the parliament. This is neither a criticism of the legal opinions or those who sought them, but it is the reason why some of the legal concerns raised in the inquiry are not relevant to what the JCPA is recommending in this particular report.

The committee has attempted in this report to allay fears about the appointment of the Auditor‐General as an independent officer of the parliament, outlining in some detail what the JCPA means by the title and recommending provisions to be included in the Auditor‐General Bill to clarify the meaning and intended ramifications of this title. In the JCPA's legislative model for guaranteeing the independence of the Auditor‐General, both the position of the Auditor‐General and the Australian National Audit Office would be established as statutory offices for which the Prime Minister would take portfolio responsibility.

An important element of the new framework to underpin the independence of the Auditor‐General is the establishment of an Audit Committee of Parliament. The Audit Committee on behalf of the parliament would enhance the transparency of decisions taken in relation to the Auditor‐General. In particular, the Audit Committee would approve the appointment of the Auditor‐General, examine the proposed appropriations for the Australian National Audit Office and make recommendations to the parliament and to the executive on appropriate levels of resourcing. It would also monitor any executive directions to the Auditor‐General, approve the appointment of the independent auditor and advise the independent auditor of parliament's audit priorities.

In his letter of referral, the Minister for Finance confirmed his intention to seek cabinet agreement that the JCPA be given the functions of an audit committee. The JCPA is enthusiastic about the prospect of becoming the Audit Committee of Parliament. The Audit Committee functions are an integral part of the JCPA's existing broad role of reporting to the parliament on means of improving public accountability.

In this report the JCPA has also recommended a range of measures that would be incorporated into the new Auditor‐General Bill to support the functional independence of the Auditor‐General. The committee was flying blind, not having seen the Auditor‐General Bill 1996, and thus not being in a position to suggest specific amendments or additions.

The committee has recommended that the Auditor‐General Bill provide for the Auditor‐General to have a mandate to conduct a full range of financial and performance audits across the entire public sector, including performance audits in government business enterprises. The committee has also recommended that the Auditor‐General Bill provide for the Auditor‐General to be appointed for a fixed term of 10 years.

It will be apparent in this report that the JCPA considers the independence of the Auditor‐General to be absolutely fundamental to public accountability in Australia. If the Auditor‐General is not properly resourced or does not have the legislative mandate to carry out an effective and broad scrutiny of the public sector, then parliament itself is compromised in its ability to hold the executive to account.

PARA.BREAK: I commend this report to the parliament. I urge all senators to take an interest not only in this report but in the work of the Auditor‐General, whose future effectiveness will have a major impact on the effectiveness of parliament itself. This report contains a series of recommendations which pose a challenge to government. If adopted, these recommenda tions will go a long way to restoring authority and meaning to the parliament and securing the Auditor‐General's independence from the executive. It has taken seven years to get to where we are today, and I regard this as a hallmark decision.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, I would like to thank my colleagues on the JCPA, all those who gave evidence to the inquiry, and the JCPA secretariat whose collective commitment to the task has enabled the committee to table this report within two months of receiving the reference as requested by the minister. In particular, I would like to thank the chairman of the committee, my colleague Mr Somlyay MP.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
