Senator Hill claimed that to produce all those documents would cost the government a further $40,000. I challenge Senator Hill to provide the basis for that calculation. Senator Hill went on to say:
I have tried to use FOI principles as a guide, as was the practice of my predecessor.
This is the height of hypocrisy for someone who when in opposition argued long and hard, argued vociferously time and again, that those sorts of grounds do not apply to returns to order.

We really still have to hear an explanation of the blatant contradiction between Senator Hill's statement at estimates—confirmed this week at question time in this chamber—that he and he alone made the decision on the Port Hinchinbrook development on 22 August. The statements of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer) a month earlier that the government had approved the project and that the Prime Minister had been personally involved were both downright lies. That is what the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) said at estimates and that is what he said in this chamber.

We believe it is appropriate that this very limited return to order for the production of documents should be supported by this chamber. I hope that some of these documents will shed some light—some light that you do not want to see, Senator Hill—on the continuing contradiction between what Senator Hill has said and what the Prime Minister and the Deputy Prime Minister have said.

I want to say on behalf of the opposition that we do not intend to rest until we have nailed this matter down and nailed the responsible culprit, Senator Hill, who has not fulfilled his statutory responsibilities in this regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—You can laugh, but this is a serious matter not only in relation to the protection of the environment but in terms of properly administering your portfolio and properly taking account of your ministerial responsibilities. This motion and the substantive motion has the support of the opposition. (Time expired)
—Hear, hear!
—Hear, hear!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —When you have to applaud yourself, I can only suggest that you are desperate for support. Senator Faulkner dealt with two matters because of the pressures of other business—
—I hope you appreciate that.

—I said I was happy to do that to facilitate his other requirements. But really this debate is not about the merit of the motion at all; this debate is about whether there has been urgency demonstrated that would justify a suspension of standing orders so that this matter would take priority over all other matters on the Notice Paper . Very little effort was made by Senator Woodley in his contribution to achieve that objective.

PARA.BREAK: Just to make it absolutely clear again, even before there was any return to order passed in this chamber, I voluntarily tabled all of the key advices and documents in relation to consent I gave, in order to demonstrate transparency of government practice and, as I said at that time, in order for honourable senators to make a judgment on performance in relation to my obligations. I was more than happy to do it. I tabled it willingly. Some body else calculated that that was some 2,000-odd pages of material.

SPEECH.PARA: Then, subsequently, a return to order was made asking for practically every document imaginable. It was a return to order put in the broadest of terms. That required, obviously, an enormous amount of work. As a result of that, at the first opportunity I was able to I tabled that material in the Senate during the adjournment debate the other night. Somebody has calculated that as being in the vicinity of 10,000 pages of material.

Still not satisfied, senators from the other side come in here seeking more. Furthermore—and this was not within Senator Woodley's return to order—I tabled the formal reasons for my decisions, which will be the subject of the current court litigation. That is worth remembering also because, although Senator Woodley says there is great urgency in relation to this matter, it is now in the courts and the courts in accordance with due process will no doubt take some time to resolve the matters.

So the courts will pass judgment and the Senate has before it an enormous volume of material upon which to pass judgment. But on top of that, Senator Woodley comes in here today and says he needs another return to order and he needs it today—no reason why it cannot wait until next week and no reason why it cannot be debated in general business under the normal way. All of a sudden it has such enormous priority that it should be given precedence over all other business on the Notice Paper of this Senate.

There is no case that has been made out in these circumstances for that urgency. Interestingly, it does not even relate to documents within my control. It relates to documents alleged to be signed by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer).

I would have thought that, at the very least, Senator Woodley would have given us the opportunity to discuss what was being sought with both of those two parties. That is why notice of motion is normally given and is subsequently debated after a reasonable period of time. But there was no such courtesy from Senator Woodley in this matter. He has thousands and thousands of pages of material on the public record already but, being dissatisfied with what he has got from me, he now wants to go after the Prime Minister and the Deputy Prime Minister as well, without making any case for that at all. He has no concern about what it has cost the people so far in dragging all these documents out.

Senator Faulkner asked where the $40,000 came from. My advice is that we have to search the bottom of the e-mail trail, the hard disk e-mail records, and that it would cost in the vicinity of $40,000. That is the advice I have been given. I have not calculated what it has cost the taxpayer to date to meet the requirements of Senator Woodley, but it has been a considerable sum of money as well.

Furthermore, I tabled the documents as rapidly as I could and, therefore, it was impossible within that time to have them indexed. I have offered to the Senate, because I think the Senate officials are put in a very difficult position here, to have my department subsequently index those documents for them. We have bent over backwards to meet the requirements of Senator Woodley. No urgency has been made out, and this should be defeated. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —A very clear and cogent case exists for the urgency of this matter. Work is proceeding for the resort at Hinchinbrook that the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) has given the go ahead for. There has been an injunction holding up that work, but that injunction was lifted last week. Amid claims of environmental damage, the developer, Mr Williams—who has no record of environmental sensitivity which I would accept as legitimate—has begun what will end up being a very destructive process of establishing a completely unwarranted and untoward development in the region of the World Heritage areas of the Great Barrier Reef and the wet tropics.

PARA.BREAK: The minister says there is no urgency. That is because he is becoming a master of the pre-emptive. His delivery of the documents to Senator Woodley to the Senate at midnight the other night shows how sneaky the process can become when there is simple manoeuv ring going on by the minister to hide from the real debate, which is his abrogation of authority as chief environmentalist in this country when giving the go ahead for this destructive proposal on the Hinchinbrook Channel.

SPEECH.PARA: He says that he withheld internal memos. I, for one, want to see them. I think everybody involved in this process wants to see them. He says there is transparency even though we cannot see. He has failed to respond properly to Senator Woodley's prior request for a return of all information to the Senate. He says that those internal memos are not our business, or are too hard to get or are going to cost money. They are sitting on his desk. He says he cannot get the e-mail or he has not got e-mail to provide us, which is a clear come on to anybody who wants to be secretive in the future to exchange information with Senator Hill's office by e-mail.

That is the way you are going to be sheltered. He is going to hide that from those people in the public who want to know what this minister is doing when, on the one hand, he purports to be the Minister for the Environment and, on the other hand, he is saying, `Go ahead,' to Keith Williams. It would be nice if he would modify this destructive proposal. When Keith Williams says, `No, it's the mega-proposal or nothing,' the minister goes weak at the knees and says, `Let's have the mega-proposal.'

Already we know that there has been further environmental damage at the site over the weekend. It is posited in all sorts of terms about what is minimal and acceptable and so on, but environmentalists on the scene reported damage to the mangroves by the removal of dead logs coming from previous destructive activities of Keith Williams and his bulldozers on this fragile site. The authorities themselves—and I mean by this the authorities under the protection of this minister—have reported that they had to remove plants for later replanting elsewhere, because they would have been destroyed by Mr Williams's activities.

So you cannot have it both ways. On the one hand, the destruction has begun under this minister's go ahead and, on the other hand, he says it is not urgent to give information to Senator Woodley. What is he coming at? That is an insult to the Senate's intelligence. It is an insult to the people of Australia who are watching this issue and the people at Hinchinbrook, and in Queensland in particular, who are horrified by this mega-proposal, by this mega-developer who has caused such environmental crassness in his previous developments such as the one at Hamilton Island.

So the matter is urgent. We are well aware that this minister, instead of standing up for the environment, is becoming a master at subterfuge and at doing everything he can to hide the facts which this Senate ought to be delivered with. (Time expired)

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Woodley's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Woodley, on behalf of Senator Kernot) proposed:
That general business notice of motion no. 240 may be moved immediately and have precedence over all other business today till determined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose that motion. A number of matters have come before this chamber which have been outstanding for some considerable time. I voted for the suspension of standing orders because ultimately I believe that this matter ought to come before the chamber before it is due to come before the chamber—but not now. This particular motion is to have this matter take precedence over all of the other matters that are before the chamber and I do not agree with that. I agree that it ought to be dealt with today at some stage, but there are other matters that have been on the Notice Paper for a considerable period of time, not least of which are the disallowance motions put forward by Senator Bolkus.

SPEECH.PARA: We in this chamber have a number of responsibilities both within and outside the chamber and I believe that there should be some understanding by members of the opposition, by the Australian Democrats, by the Greens and by the government that these responsibilities require an enormous amount of time. It is no good having a situation where we do not know from one minute to the next what is going to happen in this chamber. One is trying to discuss matters with advisers and with other people about a range of issues and one is waiting to see when matters such as Senator Bolkus's disallowance motions are going to be debated.

Frankly, I would prefer to have this matter come on immediately after we dispose of the matter that has been going on for two or three days, namely the disallowance motion, if that is the desire of Senator Woodley. I want to get it out of the road.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been here all morning—waiting.
—I waited half the day too, but I feel, in all fairness, that if we could get that one out of the road then we could come back to yours.
—by leave—If the government and the opposition are prepared to accept that proposal of Senator Harradine, I am also prepared to accept it.
—So the question is that the motion of precedence moved by Senator Woodley be agreed to.
—As I understand it, Senator Harradine suggested that this matter should come on later today for debate and I think the opposition is happy to accept that, as, I think, is Senator Woodley.
—Senator Schacht is quite right and added to that was the recognition that it would be debated later today and would come on immediately after the matter that Senator Bolkus has before the Senate.
—Senator Woodley, you will have to amend your motion because there has been a change to what you originally proposed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure the government would like me to forget about it, but I will not. I therefore seek leave to amend my motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion now reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: That general business notice of motion No. 240 standing in my name for this day, relating to the production of documents by the Minister representing the Prime Minister (Senator Hill) concerning the Port Hinchinbrook project, be an order of the day after business of the Senate No. 5.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask where that leaves the general business items listed for today that are to come on no later than 4.30. I want to put a few things on the record. There is a concern to complete the disallowance motions. Having looked around the chamber last night and got some feedback this morning, I think there is a fair chance that there are probably four speakers to go on the disallowance motions, together with the reply, which may consume all the time that we have this afternoon. If we were to put this motion on after the disallowance, we would have problems there.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite Senator Harradine's concern, I would be more inclined to have this motion dealt with now than to take a chance on whether or not we would finish the disallowance motions. I am also concerned that we do have an order for this afternoon which takes us to the end of general business and I would be very concerned if we interrupted anything between 2 p.m. and the completion of the general business items, No. 15 in particular. I am sure senators would also be concerned. I suggest that we either go ahead with it now or we list it after general business and make it come on after item No. 15 for the day.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have an amended motion by Senator Woodley. Is there any further debate before we put the question?
—I seek clarification of precisely what the position is before the chair at this stage.

—As the chair understands it, Senator Woodley's amended motion omits the word `forthwith' and substitutes `after business of the Senate order of the day No. 5'. As I understand it, that would have precedence over other matters until 2 p.m. and again at 4.30.
—As I understand it, at 4.30 general business will come on. The effect of this motion will not be to take precedence over general business at 4.30.
—The chair understands that it will take precedence over all other business at 4.30.

—I suggest that the original motion be taken, that this matter be dispensed with—it will not take long—and that we proceed as we were at the outset. I think that is the sensible decision to make and, with goodwill on both sides, the matter can be debated and, if necessary, put to a vote and got out of the way.
—Could you just clarify what you mean, Senator Brown?
—Yes, that Senator Woodley's original motion calling for this matter to be dealt with now be put, that we proceed with a short debate on it, the vote, and then move on to the other—
—That would require Senator Woodley to withdraw his amended motion.
—That is correct.
—By leave of the Senate. Is Senator Woodley prepared to do that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I am prepared to help the Senate. I would expect it to be better to proceed with this matter now, so I seek leave to withdraw my amended motion and proceed with the original.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
Amendment (by Senator Hill) proposed:
Omit "immediately", substitute "after the determination of business of the Senate order of the day No. 5 (Court fees regulations—Motion for disallowance)".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to oppose the motion moved by Senator Hill. I remind the Senate of Senator Bolkus's words a short while ago on the disallowance motion that is in continuation before the chamber. We suggest that there are at least four speakers who will want to speak on that. I will be in continuation. As I understand it, I have 28 minutes to go in my contribution to the debate. If the speakers who follow me also use their time, it will take us well beyond 12.45 when the business of the Senate changes.

SPEECH.PARA: In my opinion, we will not finish today the debate on the disallowance motion. When Senator Woodley moved for the suspension of standing orders, which was carried by the Senate, he said that he wanted this matter discussed and debated today, not at the conclusion of the disallowance motion, which may not now be completed today. I do not know what the government is doing, wasting the time of the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't know what you are doing.

—No, you are the people who opposed the suspension of standing orders, resulting in a half hour debate on the motion to suspend standing orders. You have lost it. You are not willing to cop it sweet now that you have lost that particular debate. You should allow the debate to go ahead on the substantive motion that Senator Woodley has put before you. Then, with a bit of luck I might have the opportunity of finishing those words of wisdom that I started to deliver to the chamber last night on the disallowance motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —This really does show to the Democrats and the Greens that you cannot mess around with the program of the chamber. You get yourself into all this sort of stupidity and ridiculousness. Look at this huddle over here. This is just ridiculous. It just shows the Greens, the Labor Party, the Democrats—
—A full caucus meeting.

—A full caucus meeting. If anyone was ever in any doubt whatsoever as to the way the Labor Party and the Democrats get together, they only have to see this today. It does show what happens when you try to hijack the efficient order of the chamber from the program that was agreed upon some time ago. The Labor Party obviously want to deal with the matter that is in continuation. They have something on this afternoon, and the Democrats and the Greens get together with the Labor Party again to mishandle all of that.

SPEECH.PARA: As for Senator Brown having the impertinence to suggest that it will be a short debate and will not take long, I can assure Senator Brown that he does not speak for me and I think I can quite genuinely say that he does not speak for any of my colleagues on this side. He may think the debate will be short, but other senators may have different views. So it is quite impertinent to suggest that that is the case. Again, I just point out the stupidity of hijacking the government's program.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I assure Senator Ian Macdonald that I do not speak for him. I never have, I never will and I never want to.
—You wouldn't want to be in the same room as him!

—Exactly. On the amendment, to which I will speak if Senator Macdonald cannot bring himself to it, the fact is that we have got again, whatever the outcome of this, the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill ducking for cover. We are heading towards another midnight debate on this issue if the minister has his way.

SPEECH.PARA: I am happy to go along with whatever resolution of this Senator Woodley thinks is proper, but I want to reiterate to this chamber that this matter is urgent. The bulldozers and the machinery are at Port Hinchinbrook. It is quite proper that the information about what is going on, which the minister is trying to hide, should be discovered. While he wants to relegate the debate to another midnight session, when everybody else is tucked up in bed, so that he can go about his secret way of trying to do in the environment, I am not inclined to go along with him.

The reaction from the other side seems to indicate that what I am saying is touching a nerve and that I am spot on. If it has got the members opposite galvanised, at least it might get their attention on to this hugely important environmental issue, which Senator Woodley is quite properly trying to get some information on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I suggest that, in view of the confusion we have in the chamber at the moment, and in view of—I cannot help myself—the extremely offensive remarks of Senator Macdonald—Senator Ian Macdonald, I hasten to say; Senator Sandy Macdonald doesn't do it—
—Senator Sandy Macdonald is the nice one.

—Thank you, Senator Collins. I suggest that the most efficient way for the Senate to go about this now would be for Senator Woodley to seek leave to bring this motion up again on Monday. He can speak to Senator Hill in between, and perhaps they can smooth out their differences. Perhaps we can then go through this extremely efficiently and have it as a formal motion on Monday.
—It is first necessary for Senator Hill to withdraw his amendment. Senator Hill, are you prepared to withdraw your amendment?
—Yes, I withdraw my amendment.
—Thank you, Senator Bourne, for your assistance. I now call Senator Woodley.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to do whatever is necessary to ensure that this motion will be deferred and will be debated on Monday.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; motion withdrawn.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Thank you for those comments. Exactly one hour ago I stood in this chamber—
—You were right.

—Thank you, Senator Ray, I was right. As I was saying, that was exactly the offer I made one hour ago. Senator Brown, we were not trying to stop this debate. We wanted to have an ordered debate. Recognising at that stage that things were not ready to proceed, we made the offer to defer consideration of this matter until Monday. I am glad to see that, an hour later, that has finally been accepted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, under standing order 191—
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. What right does Senator Macdonald have to just stand and address the Senate?
—He said 191.
—He did not take a point of order. If he is taking a point of order, he is entitled to, but he just stood up and addressed you, Mr Acting Deputy President.
—Senator Macdonald is quite in order. I ask Senator Macdonald to continue. He is in order.

—Fortunately you, Mr Acting Deputy President, know the rules. The Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Faulkner) has no idea, but he has no idea about anything. Under standing order 191, I think what I said before was misunderstood by Senator Bourne, who has now gone.
—No, I haven't.
—She suggested that what I said was offensive. If she thinks that is offensive, she will be surprised when I really do try to be offensive.
—This is just gratuitous rubbish, Senator, and wasting time.

—That is your view, Senator Collins, but I simply wanted to say to Senator Bourne that, if she thought I was being offensive, she was wrong. I do not want her to misunderstand. The point of my speech, which I think she did misunderstand, was simply that I think it is ridiculous that parties like yourselves and the Greens—

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order.
—Order! If those on my left could keep their noise down a bit, I might be able to understand the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate when he tries to take a point of order.
—I ask you, Mr acting Deputy President: given the circumstances with which Senator Macdonald rose to his feet, is he now in order in addressing the chair in this way?
—Senator Macdonald, I do not believe you are putting your remarks through the chair. Have you finished your point of explanation?

—Almost. I do apologise for not speaking through the chair. My speech was misunderstood and I am just explaining how it should be understood. I was saying that Senator Bourne misunderstood something I said as being offensive. It is simply ridiculous that parties like the Democrats and the Greens—
—Mr Acting Deputy President, point of order: you might like to tell Senator Macdonald that I now understand perfectly what he was saying and that there is no further need for him to progress.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: BROWN

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on the point of order. Standing order 191 says:

INTERJECT.PARA: . . . no debatable matter shall be brought forward or debate arise on such an explanation.
Clearly, the senator is out of order. If he does not have anything more clear cut to say which does not introduce debatable matter, he should be silenced.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I believe Senator Macdonald has finished his point of explanation; is that correct?
—In about 15 seconds I will be.
—I ask you to confine your remarks to the point of explanation. I understand that Senator Bourne has already got the drift of what you are trying to say.

—I am not sure that she has. She apparently misunderstood me. Parties like the Democrats and the Greens who have less than six per cent of the vote are hijacking the government's program. That is what I was saying before. That is the issue I wanted to raise. I am finished.
—Senator Macdonald, those final remarks of yours were debating the point rather than explaining the point. I ask you in future to confine your remarks to an explanation.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 9 October, on motion by Senator Bolkus:
That the following regulations be disallowed:
Regulation 3 of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1996 No. 187 and made under the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975.
Regulations 3 and 7 of the Bankruptcy Rules (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1996 No. 191 and made under the Bankruptcy Act 1966.
Regulation 3 of the Family Law Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1996 No. 188 and made under the Family Law Act 1975.
Regulations 3, 4, 5, 6, 8 and 9 of the Federal Court of Australia Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1996 No. 189 and made under the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976.
Regulations 3, 4, 5 and 7 of the High Court of Australia (Fees) Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1996 No. 190 and made under the Judiciary Act 1903.
Regulation 3 of the National Native Title Tribunal Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1996 No. 186 and made under the Native Title Act 1993.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying when I was interrupted last evening, if the opposition had not taken the stance that it had on these dramatic increases in court fees and charges, we would be abrogating our responsibilities as representatives of the public. Truly, what was proposed, and what still is proposed with the amendments Senator Vanstone foreshadowed last evening, is still draconian.

SPEECH.PARA: The opposition is operating under some difficulties here today in addressing this matter. Some three weeks ago, after the estimates committee processes in detail when we addressed the reasons why these charges had been increased so dramatically, we put a series of questions on notice regarding the increases in fees to the High Court, the Family Court and the Federal Court.

The opposition, and indeed the Senate, is being treated with disdain by the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) and the Attorney‐General's Department. We have not got responses to the questions that we put on notice to the Attorney-General and his department some three weeks ago. We have got somewhat of an explanation as to why we have not got answers and responses to questions by way of an undated letter from the Attorney-General to the chair of the committee, Senator Ellison. He writes:
Dear Senator Ellison
I am writing regarding the provision to the Committee of responses to questions taken on notice at the estimates hearings on 17 and 19 September 1996 for my portfolio.

You will be aware that an exceptionally large number of questions had to be taken on notice and that some of these questions are quite extensive and detailed. In addition, there was a considerable delay in the Hansard office placing the record of 19 September on the Parliamentary database for our access.
My Department and I will endeavour to provide the Committee with as many responses as possible by 4 October 1996—
today it is 10 October 1996—

and I hope to be able to provide the remainder to the Committee by 9 October 1996. However, I must note that this may not be possible in every case given the detailed nature of some of the questions asked.

Here we are on 10 October 1996 and we have not got one response to one question that was placed on notice on these very important matters. I do not know what the intent of the Attorney-General is in doing this. I do not know why he should treat the Senate with such contempt. It is something that the Senate should address. It is certainly something that the members of the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee will be addressing when the Attorney-General's Department appears before it in two weeks.

There are some difficulties—there is no question about it—because of the way the government has cut back the funds to Hansard. The Hansard is not able to be delivered in the timely manner it used to be able to be delivered. Maybe that is a decided plot by the government to keep matters hidden from the committee as well. I notice that the chair of the committee is coming into the chamber. I suspect that he will continue his remarks on the legislation committee's report to this chamber on this very important matter. Information is being denied to the Senate.

The committee met on 17 and 19 September, where we addressed questions to the Attorney-General's Department. Late on 19 September, and then on 25 September, the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs appeared before the committee. That department, which appeared two days later than the Attorney-General's Department, and in another case a week later than the Attorney-General's Department, has been able to supply the committee with responses to a large number of the questions that were placed on notice. But the Attorney-General's Department has not been able to do so. I suggest—I actually accuse—that this is a deliberate tactic by the government and the Attorney-General to keep information from the committee.

Very early in the piece—on Tuesday, 17 September—we asked what modelling had been done in the High Court of Australia and in the other courts and tribunals in relation to the impact of the fees on the public and, indeed, on the work of the court. We asked for that. The secretary to the department took the question on notice. You cannot say that that is a highly detailed question that the government may take time to answer. That is something that a couple of officers of the department would probably have sat around with over a cup of coffee, maybe even with a cigarette in the barbecue area, and worked out some details and then provided it to the committee. It was a very simple request, but it has not been delivered. It is not one of the most important questions that the committee put on notice to the Attorney-General's Department. I am not suggesting for one minute that it is.

The debate that is before the chamber is now occurring three weeks after the adjournment of the committee—actually, it is more than that because Senator Bolkus first started debate on it this day three weeks ago, but it was on the Notice Paper long before that.

The information that we requested would be helpful to us in arguing this matter before the committee. The matter that we are arguing is not an inconsequential matter, despite what Senator Abetz said in his contribution to the debate last week. The matter in front of us has prompted the Law Council of Australia, one of the premier legal bodies in this country, to write to members and senators on at least three separate occasions in the lead in to the deliberations of the Senate estimates committee which took place last month. One of the letters that was addressed to the committee was incorporated into Hansard on Tuesday, 17 September. Page SLC48 of the Hansard states:

Some idea of the impact of the fee increases in the Federal court may be ascertained by taking a typical case, say one in which a small company complains that a competitor is engaging in misleading and deceptive conduct. Under the old Schedule, the originating application would attract a filing fee of $368. That will now be $1,600, an increase of 335%. In the interlocutory stages, if (as is often the case) it is necessary to file a notice of motion, under the old Schedule the filing fee would be $62. That is now to be $246, an increase of 297%. When that notice of motion comes on for hearing, that would occur, under the old Schedule, without further fee. Under the new Schedule, that small company would need to pay $400 to the court for each half day (or part thereof) occupied. If this hypothetical case could not be settled, and had to be set down for hearing, under the old Schedule the applicant would then pay a "hearing fee" of $616. Under the new Schedule, that small company would now pay the sum of $2,000 for the privilege of having the matter set down for hearing, and this sum is no longer described as a "hearing fee". The new "hearing fee" is now a fee which accrues at the rate of $1100 per day . . .

Truly, these proposed fee increases are dramatic and, indeed, draconian. To the best of my knowledge, I have never stood up in this place and been a defender of the Law Council of Australia. I have actually very rarely been a defender of the legal profession at all; I have usually left that task to my colleague Senator Cooney and some of the members on the other side of the chamber. Usually when I have had to speak about the legal profession it has been in a critical sense.

BREAK.PARA: But on this occasion, I am quite happy to be able to stand here and defend the proposition that they are putting forward. I have no doubt that there are some corporations in this county who can afford the new fees and, indeed, will probably thrive on the fact that the new fees are there. The new fees that are being introduced and proposed by the government, and, indeed, which are actually in action and have been since 1 September, will keep many companies and many individuals out of the court system. That in itself may be a good point.

But I ask you when considering that to consider the cost of justice. Should justice be available only to those who can afford to pay for it? If that is the case, we have turned over the whole of the judicial system that we have in this country. I do not think that we should do that, and we certainly should not do that without a dramatic debate on it.

I know that the concept of user pays is something that pervaded the thoughts of many in the previous government and previous governments. It probably will pervade the thoughts of those in this government. It is worth while to read into the record what the Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia, Justice Brennan—the most senior judge in this country—had to say in a recent speech on the matter of user pays. He said:

With respect, that profoundly mistakes the constitutional function of the judicial power of the State which, as I have said, is to apply the rule of law in resolving disputes and thereby preserving the peace, order and good government of society.
The chief justice does not agree that the judicial system should be restricted only to those who can afford to enter into it. In the same speech, he said:
The courts are overburdened, litigation is financially beyond the reach of practically everybody but the affluent, the corporate or the legally aided litigant—
I want to come back to the issue of the legally aided litigant shortly—

Governments are anxious to restrict expenditure on legal aid and the administration of justice. It is not an overstatement to say that the system of administering justice is in crisis. Ordinary people cannot afford to enforce their rights or litigate to protect their immunities. To that extent, the cohesive force of the law is undermined.
They are very salutary words that ought to be digested by all in this chamber and, indeed, all who have anything to do with the legal and justice system in this country.

I am not standing here as a member of the opposition who is opposed to fees being imposed on those who want to participate or have the need to participate and be involved in the judicial system. Indeed not. It would be hypocritical for me to do so. I know that when I sat on the other side of this chamber as a backbench member of government, I in turn supported the increases in fees that were levied on people and corporations who wanted to participate in the judicial system. I never, from that side of the chamber, participated in or supported actions that go to the extent that these actions go to. I doubt very much that I would have supported them. I do believe that they are truly draconian and should be opposed and dismissed.

As I said, we have increased fees in the past. We have from time to time imposed fees where no previous fees were in existence. But, if you take the words of the minister in her contribution to this debate yesterday and the words of Senator Abetz in his contribution, you will find that the levels of cost recovery of the administration of justice were not punitive under the previous regime. They certainly were not punitive in 1992 when the then Senator Sid Spindler proposed a disallowance of the fees—that proposal was supported by the now government.

It is interesting that Senator Abetz in his contribution yesterday saw fit to use a quote from the then minister for justice, Senator Tate, and to read it into the record. I would like to do the same thing and then prove a different point from the one Senator Abetz was trying to prove last evening. In March 1992, in a Senate debate on the matter of the disallowance of judicial fees, Senator Tate said:

But, basically, the fees are being levied in order to assist the Federal Government to discharge its obligation to fund the system of justice, which we are obliged to do if our society is to remain one governed by the rule of law, and the contribution, running into some millions of dollars, certainly would be very helpful in that regard.

It may well be that $500 for a hearing in the Federal Court of Australia when one is paying thousands of dollars a day for counsel is not an extravagant amount at all. It could well be increased to help defray the costs which were otherwise borne by the ordinary taxpayers of Australia.

Coalition senators, together with the Democrats, opposed that statement at that point in time. They opposed the proposal to increase fees when it was before the Senate chamber. The figure quoted is $500. With the fees that are being considered now, we are running into the tens of thousands of dollars. I ask coalition senators: if it was quite right and proper in 1992 to oppose the introduction of an increase in fees to the level of $500, is it not right and proper at this time to oppose the introduction of and increases in fees to many tens of thousands of dollars? I say it is. I am glad to have the opportunity to stand here and make that point.

Just while I am on Senator Abetz's contribution of last evening, I would make another point; it is the one which I said I would return to. In his opening contribution, he referred to Senator Stott Despoja's contribution to the debate and then raised the matter of applications relating to domestic violence. I do not disagree with where Senator Abetz said that domestic violence applications are filed. They are filed within state jurisdictions, generally speaking, around the country. Part of the reason for that being the case is that there is then the ability for people who are making applications for orders relating to domestic violence to be legally aided.

Under the proposals of this government, the legal aid system that we enjoy in this country now will be emasculated. I would suggest that, if the attorney's proposals which restrict the use of Commonwealth funds for legal aid to Commonwealth matters only go ahead on 1 July next year, what we are witnessing now with the applications relating to domestic violence orders being filed mainly in state jurisdictions will indeed change; that people will want to file those applications in the Family Court of Australia—which, indeed, is part of the Federal Court of Australia. If that is the case, perhaps there is the need in that circumstance for them to be able to get legal aid to proceed with the filing of their applications.

I was pleased that Minister Vanstone, coming in here representing the Attorney‐General, did give some relief, as she promised she would three weeks ago, in her contribution last evening—some relief. I do not know what worth can be gained from that relief. However, going to the detail of what she said, in the first instance she talked about the Family Court and said—and I will use her words:
To partially offset this reduction, the government has decided to make a small additional increase to the fee for principal relief. The current fee will rise from $460 to $500.

I now go back to the attorney's statement that he released at the delivery of the budget and bring this relief that the minister suggested last evening into some form of perspective. On 30 August this year the fee was actually $368 dollars, it was proposed in the budget to increase it to $460, and last evening the Minister representing the Attorney‐General announced that it will be increased further—to $500. That is wonderful relief for those people who are participating in the Family Court of Australia! Just over a month ago, to make an application cost $368. That was to be increased to $460. But last evening we were told it is now going to $500. There was an offset on it, and to do the minister justice I will continue on with what she said:
We propose to reduce the fee for ancillary relief from its current level of $250 to $150.

That, again, is welcomed for what it is worth. But it should be pointed out that on 30 August this year, just over a month ago, that actual fee was nil. To make an application for ancillary relief, it did not cost you anything in August of this year—or in July, or preceding 1 September when the new fee increases that were announced in the budget came into effect. So the minister last evening graciously has reduced from $250 the fee that was announced in the budget to $150.
I will continue with Minister Vanstone's statement to the Senate last evening:

Given the high level of waiver in the Family Court and the reduction in the fee, we believe that such a fee should be well within the reach of those who do not fall into the approximately 40 per cent of those whose fees are waived. In addition—
the minister continues—
the government will reduce the one‐off hearing fee from $400 to $300 to reduce the impact of that fee.

Again, I welcome that for what it is worth. But it should be pointed out that, in August of this year or prior to 1 September, the fee that applied for the one‐off hearing was nil. We have gone from nil to $400 back to $300—nonetheless, it is a step in the right direction.
The minister last evening also announced some other decreases and changes that apply to the Federal Court. Then she stated:
There will be other reductions in fees in the Federal Court. The application fee for a non‐corporate litigant will be reduced from $800 to $500 and from $1,600 to $1,200 for a corporate litigant.
Previously there was no fee. So we accept the magnanimity of the statement of last evening! The minister then continued:
The daily hearing fees will be reduced from $550 and $1,100—
that is $550 for an individual and $1,100 for a corporate entity—
to $400 and $800 respectively.

Again, great magnanimity! The minister, however, failed to point out what the fee was prior to 1 September of this year. There has been a reduction, certainly. But in the appendices attached to the attorney's statement, which I am quoting from now, that fee up to and including 30 August this year was nil. I suppose we do have to be grateful for small mercies—small mercies, indeed! I think the Law Council of Australia, in writing and addressing letters on this matter to senators and members of the Australian parliament, did themselves and, indeed, the public of Australia a great service.

I hope that they are watching this debate with interest because it is of great concern to them—though not of concern to them in the sense that Senator Abetz raised last evening when he related these increases to the fees that lawyers charge. When I engaged in some of my attacks on the legal profession in the past, I did not do it on the basis of the fees that the individuals charged. If they can get them, fine; they can get them and get away with it. Had the legal profession and the Law Council of Australia and those other bodies sought to increase the fees of lawyers by 300 and 400 per cent, I would have stood here and condemned and attacked them—as Senator Cooney said a short while ago, viciously attacked them. I would indeed, and they would be deserving had we done so.

I do not think the Law Council of Australia has ever supported increases of the nature that is suggested and proposed—and indeed that have been implemented—by this government now. I do not think the Law Council of Australia have ever supported fees of that nature. I would hope that they will take account of what Senator Abetz said last evening and, in doing so, address their member, because he did admit in the debate last evening that indeed he is a member.

The final point I want to make is that a great deal of store has been put in what the cost recovery is from state judicial jurisdictions as opposed to what it is from the federal jurisdictions. In the figures that were given, I do not know why 1989 was used. Had we more time in the debate, I think it would be worth while putting further questions—or perhaps I am flagging questions for the estimates committee proceedings in two weeks time—to get the cost recovery figures from each of the years, not just 1989.

The figures that the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone, last evening quoted—and indeed they were quoted later by Senator Abetz—do not correlate with those figures that were provided to the senators and indeed incorporated in the Hansard at page L&C 49 on 17 September. They do not correlate at all. But we are not in a position to check because the questions that we put on notice have not yet been replied to. That is a matter that will be followed through in the Senate estimates committee. It will be followed through in this chamber as well because not only is that an insult to those members of the committee but also the Attorney's actions are an insult to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I might just address Senator McKiernan's last point first. That deals with the answers to questions on notice in relation to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee. Senator McKiernan, through the chair, I can advise from the department that there are a number of questions being answered at the moment. SPEECH.PARA: I advise Senator McKiernan that the vast majority of questions have been answered and those answers have been provided to the committee. In fact they were provided yesterday. The simple position is that the vast majority of answers have been delivered to the committee; there are some still outstanding, and those answers have been drafted and will be available to the committee shortly.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order: I am being misrepresented here. I am a member of the committee. I have not received those answers. Those answers were not in my office this morning before I came in for this debate and they were certainly not in my office prior to that recent division. I hope Senator Ellison is not impugning my integrity here.

—I did not say that Senator McKiernan had received them. The question is whether the committee had received the answers. I understand from the department that the answers are with the committee. The next step would logically be that the committee then provides the answers to Senator McKiernan. I would suggest that Senator McKiernan take it up with the committee and, no doubt, he will have his answers given to him.
—I assume, Senator Ellison, you were speaking to the point of order raised. I do not think there was a point of order, so I ask you to continue.

—Thank you. In relation to this whole question of the increased court fees, I would like to remind the opposition of its position in March 1992 when the then Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the fees are being levied in order to assist the Federal Government to discharge its obligation to fund the system of justice, which we are obliged to do if our society is to remain one governed by the rule of law, and the contribution, running into some millions of dollars, certainly would be very helpful in that regard.

He was speaking in relation to a move by the then government to increase court fees. In fact, what he was saying there was that the increased court fees would be very helpful indeed in contributing to the expensive cost of our judicial system. It would be no surprise to the community at large to know that the Family Court alone costs in the region of $100 million a year to run. But it was this opposition, which was formerly in government, that sought to increase fees. Not only did it do that, but also the previous government looked at a fees review in 1992. It made a decision last year to continue with the increase in fees.

The former government itself recognised the need to increase court fees. It recognised the need to have some sort of cost recovery in the running of our courts. In fact, as an average, the Commonwealth recovers about half of the costs that the states do. The states have a recovery rate in the region of 30 per cent. The Commonwealth, unfortunately, has a recovery rate of something in the region of 16 per cent. You have this situation where the judicial system in this country is expensive. By its very nature it is costly, and that is a fact of life. The government needs to have some recovery in relation to the running of those courts.

Of course there has to be a safety net. There are people naturally who could not afford to pay the necessary fees. So there is a provision for the waiver of fees. In the Family Court—we were told this in the estimates committee—38 per cent of applicants have their fees waived. Not quite 40 per cent have their fees waived. So if you are receiving social security or legal aid, you do not have to pay the fee. That leaves some 60 per cent of litigants who then have to look at the fee.

The government has listened to representations made to it and it has agreed that in relation to applications in the Family Court the fee will be reduced from $250 to $150. The one-off hearing fee of $400 will be reduced to $300. Let me make this point: in the Family Court only five per cent of matters go to trial; 95 per cent of matters settle. That means only a small sector of litigants will find it necessary to pay the hearing fee because most matters settle without going to trial. So in the family law jurisdiction these fees will not have such a drastic effect as the opposition would make out.

In relation to the Federal Court, the Attorney has announced that the filing fee for corporations and individuals respectively will not be as high as first proposed. For individuals it will now be $500 instead of $800. In relation to corporations, I understand the fee is coming down from $1,600 to $1,200. That affects the scenario that Senator McKiernan portrayed in relation to a small business engaged in a section 52 action which relates to misleading or deceptive conduct. He said that the filing fee would be $1,600. That is wrong because the government is now proposing it be $1,200. He said that the hearing fee would be $1,100 a day. That is now being reduced to $800 a day.

TALK.START.PARA: —And one day in court is free.

—And there is one day in court free—the first day. Senator Harradine is quite correct. So there were three aspects of the scenario that Senator McKiernan portrayed which were quite incorrect. I think it is important for the Senate to take note of that situation.

SPEECH.PARA: Importantly, the government has recognised the situation in relation to industrial relations matters. The situation there is that the filing fee will be reduced to be the same as fees in the Industrial Relations Commission. That is pertinent to unlawful dismissal matters where you would have an individual taking action against an employer.

BREAK.PARA: Another aspect that has been raised is the question of domestic violence and the use of restraining orders. Unfortunately, it is becoming a matter which is quite prevalent in our community that people have to resort to these applications but they do not go to the Family Court. Senator Abetz was quite correct when he pointed out that 99 per cent of matters would go to the magistrates courts.

Why do people go there? Because the relief is more substantive and it is instantaneous. You can obtain your relief much more quickly in the magistrates courts than you can in the Family Court. So people do not go to the Family Court for restraining orders where there is an allegation of domestic violence. They go to the magistrates courts, and those courts are not affected at all by any of these proposals. For the purposes of this debate, the question of domestic violence is really quite irrelevant.

With respect to the proposals in relation to family law, I would point out that only form 7 applications attract a fee. Form 8 applications do not attract a fee. Form 8 applications are quite important during the course of an action because they can relate to such matters as urgent access. It may be that a party to a Family Court action is being denied access and they make an urgent application. That urgent application would not attract a filing fee. I believe it is quite appropriate that it not attract a filing fee as such. The initial fee is paid when a form 7 application is lodged and that is it. It is a one-off payment.

The government has to address the budget deficit. This measure, as has been stated, would look at addressing that in part in relation to the judicial system. A figure of over $100 million was mentioned over the period of four years. That is a substantial amount. As I pointed out, the opposition when it was in government recognised what an important issue this was. In 1992, the opposition when it was in government—when Senator Bolkus was a minister in that government and when Senator McKiernan was a part of that government—tried to raise court fees. It tried to raise court fees because the cost of administering the courts was becoming so burdensome on the taxpayer.

I also concede the point that even then the opposition recognised there should be a safety net, that people on legal aid should not have to pay the filing fee. We, too, with these proposals recognise that safety net. It is not a question of anyone who is in pecuniarius having to pay these fees because they can apply to have them waived. There is a form they can fill in and a means test can be applied. If they are on legal aid the fees are automatically waived. If they are on social security the fees are waived. These fees will not have as wide an application as the opposition would make out.

I believe that the question Senator McKiernan raises in relation to the civil action of a section 52 matter is incorrect. One point that should be made is that most of those sorts of actions would be conducted in state courts in any event. So that would not apply.

I deny emphatically that there has been any conspiracy in relation to the Attorney‐General's Department to deny answers to the estimates committee. The department, I believe, cooperated fully with the estimates hearing which lasted some 18 hours, if I recall. There was some 18 hours of evidence and I believe the department was very good in the way it cooperated with the committee and in the answers it gave.

I have put to the Senate the logistical situation that Hansard had a lot on its plate with estimates and, in relation to the questions on notice, the Attorney‐General's Department had to have those questions before it could answer them. It has answered the vast majority. The remainder will be answered shortly. There is no conspiracy and there is absolutely no fault on the part of the department. I reject emphatically any intention by the Attorney-General to obstruct the course of the estimates process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —It will be necessary to speak only to the first of these eight bills. The seven following bills currently before the Senate are consequential bills. They are part of a package and simply set the levy rates on the particular industries involved that are required to fund the Australian Animal Health Council itself.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Animal Health Council bill and the seven consequential bills are being introduced into the chamber at this particular time because they are non-controversial bills—that is, there is no disagreement on them. It does not mean that they are unimportant bills. I do want to draw the Senate's attention to the fact that we are passing very significant legislation today for Australia that is not just of relevance to Australia's primary industry. It is of major relevance to the national economy, to the national wellbeing of this country and to the environment of Australia in a broader sense.

BREAK.PARA: I had the great privilege—and, indeed, it is a great privilege—to be the minister who had the carriage of this legislation through ARMCANZ. I mention that simply to acknowledge the full‐blooded support the Commonwealth government received from the states and from all of the state ministers for primary industry, all of whom recognised the vital importance these bills constitute today for Australia.

Australia is one of the great trading nations of the world. We are an island continent. With the level of trade increasing—and I hope it will continue to increase at an expediential rate every year—Australia needs to be prepared against an outbreak of an exotic animal disease which could absolutely devastate multibillion dollar industries for Australia not just in the immediate term or even in the medium term but in some cases in a way which might never be altogether successfully addressed. Those concerns can never be overstated.

The Australian Animal Health Council, which this bill will give life to, is going to be the foremost national body—and it will be recognised internationally with that status—to stand between Australia and that prospect. It is also being set up to deal with day-to-day problems in respect of our pro‐active position on trade. I am talking here about problems such as chemical residue in the commodities that Australia produces into our all‐important export markets.

It was absolutely essential that this national approach be taken. It was a complex matter. Many bureaucrats from both the Commonwealth and state bureaucracies cooperated fully over a long period of time in dealing with the whole range of complex issues that are normally there in this federation of ours to get the agreement necessary to put all of these things into place at both the federal level and the state and territory level. That level of cooperation was there and that is why we have got this legislation here today—the formal agreement being reached in ARMCANZ in August last year, from memory.

The other thing that needs to be noted that is also important is that the council subsumes the vitally important responsibilities of the body formerly known as EXANDIS—the Exotic Animal Disease Preparedness Consultative Council. The legislation that established EXANDIS lapsed in December last year. This body subsumes the responsibilities of EXANDIS.

In its final annual report, EXANDIS urged all governments and industry to maintain through this body an extremely high level of continued activity at protecting Australia against the outbreaks of exotic diseases that I have just referred to.I want to pay tribute—as I am sure the government would pay tribute—to the work that was done by EXANDIS in assisting Australia to maintain those protections and in assisting in the formation of the body that we are giving birth to here today.

It is worth while pointing out because it is always a matter of topical discussion in this country—and so it should be—that, in the handover set of recommendations, if you like, contained in the final EXANDIS annual report, EXANDIS considered that foot‐and‐mouth disease, newcastle disease, blue tongue and classical swine fever remained the major potential exotic disease problems for this country.

As I said, all these things will always be topical. Newcastle disease obviously is in the news right now as the major concern of the Australian chicken meat industry, as there is a proposal currently before us to import chicken meat from Thailand—a country, of course, in which newcastle disease is endemic. These will always be issues of topicality in a country such as ours that depends entirely, as we do, on the health of our trade for our national economy.

PARA.BREAK: There are just a few things that were recommended by EXANDIS as well that I do want to simply draw attention to very briefly. One—and it is a matter that was brought to me on a number of occasions—was the concern that EXANDIS had about the recognised current deficiency in the epidemiological database in Australia, which is needed for a totally effective disease surveillance system in this country. It was a matter that was drawn to my attention on a number of occa sions by EXANDIS during its life. It took the trouble to note in its final annual report that this is a matter that should be of continuing concern for the body that we are launching here today—the AAHC.

BREAK.PARA: EXANDIS also called upon the AAHC to continue the national disease‐watch hotline to facilitate reporting and investigation of any unusual animal incidents in all states and territories and to ensure that the necessary resources are made available for this service to continue. Again, I guess this is something that we are so conscious of in those areas of Australia that are so close to the countries where these diseases are endemic. Things like screw-worm fly—which, thank God, do not exist in Australia yet—are just hundreds of kilometres away from our shores. There is the never-ending potential for destructive pests such as screw-worm fly to enter Australia and cause consequent devastation to Australian industry. Of course, there is no need to canvass the never-ending potential for foot‐and‐mouth disease outbreaks to occur in Australia.

It is not simply luck that these diseases and pests have not arrived here. Luck has something to do with it. Luck always has something to do with it. It is, in fact—I am pleased to say—a high degree of management also that helps to prevent these diseases and pests from infesting our shores.

I said earlier that this is not and cannot be considered to be an issue that simply affects primary industry or primary producers. The introduction of a disease like newcastle disease into Australia—a disease that EXANDIS rates among that handful of half a dozen diseases of the highest exotic disease concern to Australia—would have a devastating effect on the Australian environment at large. It is a disease which, if it ever got a foothold in Australia and got into the wild population of birds in Australia, would be almost impossible thereafter to ever eradicate; it would simply become part of our disease landscape as well as those of the countries that are close to our shores.

So I say, and I will not need to speak again during this debate on the other seven bills, that this is extremely important legislation that we are passing through the Senate. I do want to once again express my thanks on behalf of the opposition to a very dedicated group of public servants and bureaucrats, at both state and federal level, that has worked extremely hard to see the implementation of the Australian Animal Health Council. It has a vitally important role to carry out for Australia, and I wish it well. I certainly pledge the complete support of the Australian Labor Party, the opposition in the Senate, in terms of its future operations.

I will conclude on one small point of detail. There was some concern expressed, and there was some lack of certainty, about whether the Australian Animal Health Council would have to, or would be required to, report on its operations to the parliament through the estimates committee process. That matter has been resolved—certainly to my satisfaction. The answer to that particular question is yes, it will. The payments that are made to it—by this legislation, I might add—that constitute those levy collections do, in fact, provide the grounds for that reporting to be done. That is an important matter for all members of this parliament. They can be assured that the Australian Animal Health Council will, if it is required to do so, appear before Senate estimates committees to give reports on its progress.

—I will not respond to all of your interjections, Senator Panizza, because I do not want to take up the time of the Senate.

—I will take your very wise advice. Figures show that farmers receive a much higher amount for sheep for live export—an average $24.90—than they do for sheep for slaughter—around $10.40. The meatworkers union, the AMIEU, estimates that there could be up to 10,000 people in Albany, Broome and Robb Jetty abattoirs who have lost jobs because of live sheep exports. SPEECH.PARA: The mortality rate of sheep on voyages is approximately two per cent, which does not include the death of sheep in the recent fire. Ships leaving from Australia are not required to have a vet on board, whereas in New Zealand sheep ships do require a vet on all voyages.

TALK.START.PARA: —You shouldn't say that very quickly.
—I said it very slowly, and I will have a word to the person who wrote the speech. The Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation advises that the frozen carcase trade—

BREAK.PARA: Senator Brownhill interjecting—

BREAK.PARA: Some of the questions which I would like the minister to address are as follows. Does the government have a comment on that report of the former Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare? Would the government indicate whether or not it believes the recommendation of the committee that there should be an effort to phase out the live sheep trade in favour of the carcase trade.

I would like the minister to indicate whether the AAHC will address animal welfare issues.
