TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Minister, now that we have had a clear admission from the Assistant Treasurer this morning that he has breached the Prime Minister's ministerial code of conduct, can you inform the Senate why the Prime Minister did not take action six months ago to ensure compliance with his code, or does the Prime Minister believe that Senator Short's continued holding of ANZ shares is proper conduct in accordance with the code?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —As I recall what the Assistant Treasurer said this morning—I remind the Senate that this matter has already been debated once today—it was that, although he did not believe that there was a conflict, he nevertheless accepted that it could be perceived to be and that, in those circumstances, he has made the decision to divest himself of those shares. As I recall it, he made the additional points that they were shares that had been held for a long period of time. There was no suggestion of trading. There was no suggestion that he had in any way used information from his office to benefit himself personally. So it comes down very much, I might suggest, to a technical matter. He nevertheless—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know why the Labor Party is so fussed, because Senator Short has accepted that it nevertheless might be perceived to be in conflict and has therefore taken the precautionary action of instructing the disposal of the shares. With regard to the—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why? In accordance with the way you want me to answer questions, I can only refer that back to the Prime Minister.

—I ask a supplementary question of the minister: given the failure of the Assistant Treasurer to divest himself of all shareholdings which conflict with his ministerial responsibilities—as is required under the Prime Minister's code of ministerial conduct—will the Prime Minister now sack Senator Short? Or is weakness going to triumph with the Prime Minister and he will take no further action and, of course, yet again reveal that his commitment to his own code of ministerial conduct is nothing more than lip‐service?
—The Prime Minister requires a high standard of conduct from ministers. I do not even recall a code of conduct under the Labor Party. Nevertheless, that—
—Tell us about the piggery!

—I did not want to get into debate about Mr Keating's record or former Senator Richardson's record, because the important point is that the Prime Minister has set down a code of conduct. He expects that code of conduct to be adhered to. If it is not, he will take action as he deems appropriate.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Can the minister please advise the Senate whether the points made by Senator Kerry O'Brien in his maiden speech to this chamber on Tuesday regarding the likely impact in Tasmania of a partial sale of Telstra are correct?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is fair to start off by saying that a new senator is entitled to some latitude in this chamber, but it is also equally important, I think, that people around Australia—particularly those in Tasmania—are not misled by some of the statements that are made. Therefore, I think it is necessary for me to correct the record on a couple of important matters.

ANSWER.PARA: Firstly, the claim was made that job cuts have occurred under the guidance of the previous board of Telstra. I think that is really saying that, under the ALP, Telstra embarked on an efficiency drive which was necessary at that time in order to ensure that it could compete effectively and deliver lower prices to consumers. It is doing precisely the same thing again. It has nothing to do with privatisation. Senator O'Brien went on to say:
There is no reason to think that the likely reduction in the number of its employees by 500 to 700 will be changed by the new board.

I do not know where these figures come from. The total number of Telstra jobs in Tasmania in 1995‐96 was 1,460. If there was that sort of reduction you would be talking about up to 50 per cent of Tasmanian jobs being lost. That is simply by no stretch of the imagination even possibly—

TALK.START.PARA: —So it is only 40 per cent, is it?

—The true figure, Senator Kim Il‐Carr, is two per cent: less than two per cent of jobs in Tasmania will become redundant in 1996‐97. Those figures are completely and utterly wrong. I hope that Senator O'Brien has not been getting his information from Senator Schacht who, I presume, is still busy slaving away on his ABC submission. How is it going?
—What is it to you?

—Still working on it? If you want extra resources, let us know. I can understand why Senator Schacht finds it necessary to discover diversions such as the ABC, because he was running around in Tasmania as well a few months back saying that 500 jobs would be lost. So I hope that we have put those sorts of misleading statements to rest once and for all.
—A third of the jobs are going in Telstra.
—Sorry? You have not got the submission done yet? I am sorry, I cannot help you. The second part of the speech, which I think also deserves to be addressed, is the statement:

ANSWER.PARA: Worse than that, with the part‐privatisation of Telstra, Tasmania will lose the benefits of cross‐subsidisation of its telephone and related services that a publicly owned system brings.

This seems to have been borrowed from another new recruit to the debate, Senator Allison, who is running around suggesting that cross‐subsidisation would disappear if Telstra were partially privatised. Of course, the fact is that this is absolutely incorrect. Anyone who has read the Telecommunications Act—I suspect that not too many have—would know that there is already a provision entrenched in that legislation which guarantees that, to the extent that services in rural and remote areas are uneconomic, they must be cross‐subsidised out of a universal service fund contributed to by all the carriers on a pro rata basis.

That will continue unless, of course, the Labor Party is proposing to move an amendment to open the system up. I am not aware of that. Maybe Senator Schacht has it up his sleeve for later on. But I would not support it, I have to tell you, Senator Schacht. If you want to remove the current legislative prohibition on the guarantees, the cross‐subsidies to rural and remote areas, you should tell us about it now, but, for one, I could not support it in a fit. It would be very unfair. It certainly would not be in the best interests of Tasmanians or in the best interests of the country.

Just to make doubly sure that those arrangements stay in place, we have reaffirmed the commitment in the Telstra (Dilution of Ownership) Bill. So it is going to be there in spades. I do not know why you would want to remove that. It seems extraordinary to me and I hope you will reconsider. I know it is an important issue and I know you want to take it seriously. If you want some advice on that, we are happy to give it to you, but I am putting you on notice here and now that we are not prepared to support any amendment that you might move on that basis.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Calvert, Sen Paul

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Thank you for that answer, Minister. Could you set the record straight regarding any other matter raised by Senator O'Brien regarding the impact of the partial sale of Telstra on Tasmania?

QUESTION.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—Are you going to rule on that or should I take a point of order, Madam President?
—Order! I have serious doubts about whether that question is in order, but I heard only the first half of it. I did not hear the whole of the question. Would you state it again.
—Madam President, I asked: could the minister set the record straight about any other matter raised by Senator O'Brien regarding the likely impact of the partial sale of Telstra on Tasmania?
—I did not hear the question the first time. As presented then, the question would be in order to the extent that it is part of Senator Alston's portfolio.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —There is one other matter and I think it is important.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators—Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —I know you are surprised. I was surprised, but when I discovered it I thought it needed to be addressed. It is basically the suggestion that Tasmanians will lose access to broadband systems. The fact is there are already a number of regional carriers that are providing these sorts of services—Paynet Telecommunications in Cairns, Northgate Communications in Ballarat. Austar is very keen to cable up rural areas and Optus has indicated an interest that will extend to Tasmania. I have no doubt that if Tasmanians are interested in the service Telstra will be looking at it as well.

ANSWER.PARA: The important thing in all this is that Senator O'Brien really should not be singled out too much because he is one of seven new ALP senators to come in here since the last election. Every one of those seven is an outcast from the trade union movement. This is a retirement home for failed union officials and I can understand the acute conflict of interest you have, on the one hand wanting to address the real issues but on the other hand being beholden to the blokes who put you there in the first place. It is very sad indeed—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—that Senator Robert Ray has not been able to recruit any decent people from the real world and I just hope the situation will change.
—Order! Senator Alston, you should not go on beyond your time or beyond the time I call you to order.
—I am sorry, Madam President.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill. I ask: by what date were ministers required to provide details of their interests to the Prime Minister? Did the Prime Minister personally examine the statements of interests or did he delegate that responsibility to a staff member? If so, who was that staff member? I further ask: why did the Prime Minister not require Senator Short to divest himself of shareholdings which conflict with his ministerial responsibilities, as is required in the ministerial code of conduct?

—Some of those questions are obviously matters of detail that even Senator Faulkner would not expect me to have here today, but I will seek answers to them. One important point that seems to be overlooked in this little side debate is that there has been no alleged conflict of interest in this matter.
—There has been. It was put to you by Senator Sherry.

—No, Senator Sherry is shaking his head because this morning when it was put to him in the debate, `What conflict of interest do you allege?' his answer was that he was not specifically alleging a conflict of interest. So the issue is simply whether the form of the document has been complied with. Senator Short's answer was basically whilst he believed that was so, he nevertheless conceded that it may be interpreted that it was not so and he therefore took the action to divest himself of those shares. What action is to be taken by the Prime Minister is, of course, in the hands of the Prime Minister.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the minister: will he give the Senate a categorical guarantee, a categorical assurance, that Senator Short will not profit from his failure to comply with the ministerial code of conduct?
—Take it on notice, will you, Robert?

—That is an odd question. I am trying to interpret it. If you understand what he means, you are a step ahead of me. If you are alleging, Senator—and I hope you are not—that in some way Senator Short personally benefited from some form of inside knowledge, then I will give you a categorical assurance that that is not so. Even your colleague who led the debate this morning did not assert that. There has been no suggestion, Senator Faulkner, in this debate that Senator Short in any way benefited or in his professional capacity acted in conflict with his personal interests.

—My question is to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. It relates to the findings of the special auditor into Aboriginal organisations which, of course, revealed gross mismanagement—mismanagement and rorts which were allowed to continue under successive Labor governments.
—That is yet to be determined, I might add.

—Given that Senator Collins, who likes interjecting, has said on several occasions that the special auditor process was a waste of time and money, just how serious are the problems, Minister? Do the findings clearly vindicate the government's policy of greater accountability for all government funded organisations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator O'Chee for the question. It is a very important one. The special auditor process has been a positive step in the push for greater accountability, and I believe it has been long overdue. We can now move forward and concentrate on better service delivery in indigenous communities and improved living conditions for indigenous people. ATSIC has agreed to complete the special auditor process and use the material provided and gathered by the special auditor to assist in funding decisions.

ANSWER.PARA: We are still awaiting the final report from the special auditor. The preliminary report, however, shows that the special auditor has found that 19 per cent of—

TALK.START.PARA: —Will you table it?

—Yes. The preliminary report shows that 19 per cent of all organisations funded by ATSIC were in serious breach of grant conditions—19 per cent, Senator O'Chee—and 60 organisations which received $27.8 million in their last ATSIC grants should be declared not fit and proper and defunded—not fit and proper and defunded.

ANSWER.PARA: At the time of the court decision, the special auditor was seeking additional information on a further 130 organisations that received $89.6 million in their latest funding. Of these organisations, the special auditor says that `there is the potential for some or all to be declared not fit and proper'. The special auditor has found a further 184 organisations were in such serious breach of grant conditions that they require immediate and close attention. They received a total of $124 million in their latest funding.

That is a total of 374 of the 1,300 organisations funded by ATSIC in serious breach—either not fit and proper or requiring immediate and close attention. Those 374 organisations received a total of $241 million in their latest ATSIC grants. As a result of the special auditor, ATSIC has implemented tighter internal funding requirements.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. In the case of the organisations which were found to be not fit and proper, do I take it that there is the potential that money which should have been available for people who were in real need never made it to the needy because of the mismanagement of the organisations in question?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. Where action is to be taken, Senator O'Chee, it is intended that services will still be provided by, perhaps, another organisation, and where criminal activity has been found it will be referred to the appropriate authorities for action.

—My question is directed to Senator Hill in his capacity as Leader of the Government in the Senate. Minister, do you concur with the statement of Senator Short that no conflict of interest exists in regard to his continued shareholdings? What steps has the Prime Minister taken to establish there is no conflict? Finally, did Senator Short comply with the guidelines of the ministerial code of conduct?

—I have already answered the last question in that I have said that, although Senator Short believed that he did, he conceded that it might be perceived that he did not and he is therefore divesting himself of the—
—That is not what the Prime Minister said.

—You are asking me the question. He will answer it in the House of Representatives and I will answer it here. Secondly, he conceded that there could be perceived to be a potential conflict of interest and he is therefore disposing of the shares. Now I cannot remember the other parts of the question.
—I will remind Senator Hill of the question.
—The other shareholdings, yes.

—I had three parts to the question. Do you concur with the statement of Senator Short that no conflict of interest exists in regard to his continued shareholdings? What steps has the Prime Minister taken to establish that there is no conflict and—this is the one I would like you to answer, Minister—did Senator Short comply with the guidelines of the ministerial code of conduct? Try it again.

—I have answered the third question three times. I do not think there is much point in answering it a fourth time. With regard to his other shareholdings, Senator Short is of the view that there is no conflict of interest in relation to those shareholdings. As I recall it, this morning he said he will keep that closely under review and if he comes to a conclusion otherwise he would dispose of them. What was the other part?
—Oh, for the third time!
—Why do you ask three-part questions?
—Can't you scratch your bum and chew gum at the same time.

—I will repeat it for the third time, Madam President, given this new precedent we have established in question time because Senator Hill is so worried by the questions he does not appear to be able to take them on board. I asked the Leader of the Government in the Senate: what steps has the Prime Minister taken to establish that there is no conflict? I would like him to answer the other part of the question: did Senator Short comply with the guidelines of the ministerial code of conduct?
—Madam President, I raise a point of order. I ask you to ask Senator Bob Collins to withdraw the comment he made to Senator Hill across the chamber. I found it totally unparliamentary.
—I did not hear it. Senator Collins, is there something you should withdraw?
—Is that question in order, Madam President? I withdraw anything that caused offence.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The second part of the three‐part question was: what steps has the Prime Minister taken to satisfy himself that there was not a breach in relation to other shares? That is for the Prime Minister to answer and I will refer that back to him.

ANSWER.PARA: What Senator Faulkner fails to understand is that the first responsibility lies with the minister concerned, not with the Prime Minister. It is up to ministers to interpret the guidelines correctly and to adhere to those guidelines. As I said, Senator Short did not believe there was a conflict. But, as it has been perceived to be a conflict, he has taken action to dispose of the shares. I do not think that you would get a better answer than that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a two‐part supplementary question.
—You just asked a supplementary question.

—I am asking a supplementary question. Firstly, Senator Hill, as Leader of the Government in the Senate, do you regret the Assistant Treasurer's handling of this matter? Secondly, I ask whether you will ask the Prime Minister to make Senator Short's declaration to the Prime Minister available to the Leader of the Opposition on a confidential basis in order to determine the accuracy of the Assistant Treasurer's statements in the Senate today.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I do not regret anything in relation to this matter.
—Come on!
—Listen to him say, `Come on.' He wants a response. Senator Short has acted properly. If there was—
—Not according to the Prime Minister.

—You are asking me the questions. I don't know why you listen to the other place all the time. Just ask me. If there was a breach, it was inadvertent. It has been perceived by some to be a technical breach. He has taken action to dispose of the shares. He has taken, therefore, every reasonable action in the circumstances. Therefore, in no way do I regret his behaviour in relation to this matter.

ANSWER.PARA: You ask in the second part of the question if I would seek advice from the Prime Minister as to whether he would make certain material, that had been provided confidentially, available to a third party, and I will refer that to the Prime Minister for his consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Minister, as you are no doubt aware, BHP Gemco manganese mine on Groote Island pleaded guilty in March this year to causing water pollution and were given a $45,000 fine for losing what was said to be at the time 900,000 litres of diesel fuel oil from its tanks down under the island. In fact, after investigations, senior management at the mine now admit that there is a minimum of 3 million litres of diesel fuel oil which has leaked from the mine's tanks down into the terrestrial environment. Others put this figure as high as 10 million litres. Have you been paying a diesel fuel rebate to this company? If so, how much? Have you deducted for the amount that is now under the island? Will your government continue to give the mine a diesel fuel rebate, if you have been doing so? Effectively, you are subsidising this company to continue damaging the environment.

—The diesel fuel rebate does not come under the department of resources, but it does happen to come under Customs. There are clear guidelines as to what the diesel fuel rebate is paid for. It may well be that you are opposed to the diesel fuel rebate—
—I didn't say that.
—You said yes?
—No, I didn't.

—You agree? You do not oppose the diesel fuel rebate? I am not sure whether the Democrats know whether they agree or disagree, but that is not unusual. If the diesel fuel being used at that particular mine, or any particular mine around Australia, was in keeping with the customs legislation, they would get the diesel fuel rebate on the fuel that was used for those mining purposes. In relation to the point you are making with regard to fuel that has disappeared, I am not too sure about that and I will just check with Customs on it. My understanding is that it has to be fuel that is actually used, but I will check that.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. When you do check, could you obviously let us know? If they are right, the amount in question owed back to the government is roughly $1 million. If the experts and those who have done the other assessment are right, there is some $3.2 million in rebate owing back to the government. Will you give an undertaking to collect it if indeed it has been paid? On the matter of principle, shouldn't any mining company found to be blatantly in breach of environment regulations be refused any further diesel fuel rebate?

—The two, I would have to say, are quite unrelated. Not only am I but also the mining companies themselves are very conscious of their environmental requirements and they do not deliberately go out of their way to waste diesel fuel or any other material they use in their mining operations. But the two are totally unrelated. The usage of fuel where it is legitimate under the Customs Act would attract the diesel fuel rebate. As I say, the environmental matters are a separate issue. The mining industry itself, as I have said—you would be aware of that—is very conscious of its responsibilities. Unfortunately, there are occasions when these things occur. As a result of that, intense investigations are going into the cause of it to ensure it does not happen in the future.

—My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. Did the Prime Minister at any stage after you lodged your confidential declaration of interests communicate with you, either directly or through a staff member, to instruct you to divest yourself of shareholdings in accordance with the requirements of the code of ministerial conduct?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —No, the Prime Minister did not, nor would I have expected him to do so because the Prime Minister has an enormous number of things to do as Prime Minister of this country. I would not have expected him to have had the time necessarily to do that. As I said this morning in response to Senator Sherry's motion—I repeat it—the fact that I owned some shares in the ANZ Bank could be construed as placing me in breach of the Prime Minister's guide on key elements of ministerial responsibility.

ANSWER.PARA: The Prime Minister, in the other place this afternoon, has said that in his view the action of not disposing until now the shares in the ANZ Bank meant I had not complied with the guidelines. I accept that view of the Prime Minister. It is a matter of judgment. The Prime Minister also said in the other place this afternoon that he accepts my statement to him in our discussion on it yesterday—that it was an oversight. I accept there could be a perception, as I said this morning, that it was a breach of the guidelines. I have taken action since then to dispose of those shares.

There is a point I want to make because I believe Senator Sherry is involved in nothing more than a very sleazy, grubby, political stunt here because the innuendo is that in some way I have had a conflict of interest. It is incumbent on Senator Sherry to give some examples of just where a conflict of interest has arisen. He has not done so to date.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister thinks so. The Prime Minister said you breached the guidelines.

—No, the Prime Minister did not say that. The Prime Minister said that in his view I had not complied with the guidelines issued by him in April. I accept that view. But there has been no example given by Senator Sherry or anybody else in terms of a conflict of interest in this matter. I would refer Senator Sherry to some of the statements of his predecessors in this place when they were in government. The senator who sits next to him now, Senator Carr, quite rightly said in May this year:

BREAK.PARA: Every day of the week all of us face the potential for conflict of interest. The real issue in terms of public policy and public behaviour is whether action is actually taken which is in conflict of interest with our responsibilities as public figures.

I accept that statement. I think Senator Carr is right. I call on Senator Sherry to either put up on this issue or shut up because this will be seen as the sleazy political deal and stunt that he is undertaking.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, will you assure the Senate that you will not profit from your failure to comply with the code of ministerial conduct?

—I have taken steps today to divest myself of my shares in the ANZ Bank. The outcome of that in terms of the situation in relation to the prices I paid for them or what the price has been over a period I really have no idea. It is a matter that I will obviously be looking at.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. What is the government's response to the grubby impropriety and failure of basic journalistic ethics involved in yesterday's calumny of Princess Diana in the global Murdoch press, including the Hobart Mercury , under banners such as `Di's sex romp exposed to the world' and `Di's striptease' and re-run today without apology as `Di's royal romp exposed as fake'? I ask the minister: given your government's system atic actions to trammel more responsible sources of information by slashing the ABC's budget and defunding consumer watchdog groups, will the government now reverse its decision, taken at the behest of Mr Murdoch and others, and hold a comprehensive independent public inquiry into media ownership in Australia as it promised before the last election?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —Clearly, the first answer is that how newspapers on the other side of the globe conduct themselves is not a matter of Australian government responsibility. From what I saw of those reports, the Sun in particular, I think, which is the principal tabloid newspaper in London, had to make an abject apology.
—I am talking about the Hobart Mercury .
—I do not read the Hobart Mercury on a daily basis, I have to confess, Senator Brown.
—Why not?

—It does not have anything about Collingwood in it, so why would I be interested? To the extent that people were held up to ridicule or contempt, they have rights of action for defamation, and presumably those rights can be exercised under English law or under any other law if you are within the jurisdiction.

ANSWER.PARA: It is really not a matter for the Australian government to have a view on that sort of behaviour. I presume that this was not a deliberate action. From all I read, they said they were misled. I think the incident came about because of a short video involving a couple of look‐alikes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you defending a London tabloid?

—I am not defending them. I have to confess I did not spend as much time on this issue as I did on some of the others. The fact is I do not think there is any suggestion this was a deliberate action on the part of the newspaper. Their faces might be very red as a result of being misled, and no doubt they will be very careful in future to ensure that this sort of conduct does not occur again. There is an equivalent to the Press Council in the UK and I assume that matters can be raised there as well.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Brown also asked me about whether indeed we would conduct a comprehensive public inquiry—and there seemed to be some tenuous link suggested between the first part of the question and the second. The fact is our commitment in our election policy was for a comprehensive public review. That review is currently taking place. It is not at the behest of Mr Murdoch or anyone else. No-one made suggestions to us about how to conduct our review. We will conduct it on our own terms, thank you very much. Everyone is entitled to put in submissions, indeed your good self.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what Costello said.

—I do not expect Senator Schacht to put in a submission, because he will not have time to do it. Unfortunately, it has to be in before the turn of the century and I do not think he will make the deadline. We expect a lot of other people to put in public submissions. It is clear to all of them that they will be expected to make those publicly available for comment, unless there are good reasons to the contrary, such as commercial‐in‐confidence reasons, in which case they will be asked to provide a summary of the principal thrust of their submissions.

ANSWER.PARA: It is going to be a public review in which you could participate because you could comment on those submissions. When we introduce draft legislation you will get another chance to have all the comment you want, as will every other commentator in the country. There will be plenty of opportunity for public input. It is a review that is long overdue.

We all know why the cross-media rules were introduced in the first place. They were introduced by Mr Keating because he hated the Herald and Weekly Times and he hated the old Fairfax organisation. He was determined to get them both. He was determined to break up what he saw as the rural fiefdoms and make sure that they were not able to run what he regarded as unhelpful comment on Labor Party performance. Everyone understands that in an age of new technology it is important to take account of those changes and the sources from which people get their information. On that basis, we will be conducting the review, not on the basis of any instructions we might have got from anyone else.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Madam President. I ask the minister: isn't it a fact that it was pressure from Mr Murdoch and other media moguls that led to the government backdown from having a public inquiry which would have brought the likes of Mr Murdoch and Mr Packer before a public inquiry into the media in Australia? Is the government by that means failing to draw to account the sort of journalism which Mr Murdoch is perpetrating not only in London but in the Australian press and which has led to this scandalous story?

—I told you it was not a fact; so you get up and ask me whether it is a fact. So I cannot take the issue much further. Let me simply say that we wanted to avoid the sort of media circus that can very easily occur when you have people who are determined to whip these issues up. We did not think it was particularly helpful. I chaired the Senate inquiry into foreign ownership of Fairfax. I saw what went on there with the media scrum. We had Bob Hawke coming along demanding to be given an opportunity to say a few words and then coming back later and refuting some of the things—
—It is amazing both egos fitted into the same room.
—It was pretty crowded; I will give you that, Bob.
—We invited him.

—We did, but, as you recall, he was desperately keen to be given special leave to make an appearance. The issue became whether Black was telling the truth, whether Hawke was telling the truth, whether he was really a hotel greeter or not and all of those sorts of peripheral personality issues that had very little to do with the public debate. We would rather debate the merits of the issue, Senator Brown, and not have that sort of media circus repeated again. (Time expired)

—My question is addressed to the Assistant Treasurer. During the last six months have you received any representations from ANZ regarding the development of your government's superannuation policies, including RSAs? Have you had any personal meetings with representatives of ANZ regarding the development of RSAs? If so, when? Are records of such meetings held on Treasury files? Don't you consider it inappropriate to have such meetings while being a substantial shareholder in ANZ? If not, why not?

—Over the last six months I have had a wide range of consultations with a wide range of representatives from a wide range of the financial community over a range of issues related to superannuation and a vast range of other issues, including, as Senator Sherry quite rightly says, RSAs. RSAs were a policy decision and commitment of the coalition a year or more before the election.
—Six years.

—In fact, as Senator Newman, says they were a commitment six years before the last election. We would be letting down the Australian public and breaking an election commitment if we did not introduce RSAs, which will be able to be provided by a very—

—I rise on a point of order, Madam President. I take a point of order on relevance. This goes to the heart of Senator Short's ministerial responsibilities. He has been asked a direct question about meetings held with representatives or other representations from ANZ specifically. I ask you to direct this minister to answer the question that Senator Sherry asked.
—There were several parts to the question that were seeking precise questions.
—Don't sleaze away from it.
—Senator Faulkner, I was speaking at the time that you interjected loudly across the chamber.
—I apologise.
—Thank you. The minister should direct himself to the substance of the question that has been asked. I would ask Senator Short to do so.

—Thank you, Madam President. With respect, I think I am directing myself entirely to the substance of the question. I was saying that I have had a wide range of consultations with a wide range of financial institutions throughout the financial sector, including the ANZ, along with other banks, life offices, credit unions and building societies. All of that vast range of the financial sector, as we announced up to six years ago, will be able to provide RSAs when the parliament so legislates. There is no secret about that. I have had no special consultations with representatives of the ANZ Bank that I have not had with scores and scores of other financial institution representatives.

—I ask a supplementary question, Madam President. When discussing the matter of superannuation policies, including RSAs, in cabinet did you declare your interest, as required by the cabinet handbook? Were your declarations recorded by cabinet officers, as is also required by that handbook, and did you excuse yourself from any such discussions?
—My holding of shares in the ANZ Bank has been public knowledge since the day that the register of senators' interests was established.
—That wasn't the question.
—Just let me finish. So it has been on the public record now for two or three years.
—What about the cabinet meeting?

—So far as cabinet proprieties are concerned, I have at all times observed the proprieties and requirements of cabinet. As you are aware, I am not a member of cabinet, and my attendance at cabinet meetings is on a limited basis.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment. Australians are becoming increasingly concerned about the quality of air that they and their children are exposed to. In fact, air pollution has been rated as the No. 1 environmental concern of Australians. Can the minister inform the Senate of what steps the government has taken to address this vital issue?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable senator for her very important question. As a Sydneysider, it is not surprising that she asked it.
—Why should you be surprised?

—I am explaining why I was not surprised. The recent State of the environment report, which I just released, said that on occasions the level of air pollution in Sydney approached that of New York and Tokyo. So it is therefore not surprising that Sydneysiders rate air pollution as the No. 1 environment issue that they face.

ANSWER.PARA: The good news is that the new government has kept another of its promises; that is, the promise to establish a major independent inquiry to examine solutions to combat urban air pollution. The national inquiry will be conducted by the Australian Academy of Technological Sciences and Engineering with the aim of exploring innovative and practical solutions to urban air pollution problems. I am pleased with the enthusiasm with which the academy has taken up this challenge. In fact, the academy advises me that even before the inquiry had been publicly announced they were already receiving offers of assistance from fellows of that academy.

There have been previous inquiries and reports into the causes and extent of air pollution. The difference with the new inquiry is that it is designed to avoid simply going over that old ground. Its terms of reference focus on identifying practical measures that can be taken by governments, industry, community groups and individuals to improve air quality in Australian towns and cities in the medium to long term.

The academy has the scientific and technical expertise required to make the assessment and to propose those practical solutions. It has a worldwide reputation for scientific excellence. Under its direction, the inquiry will address the capacity of existing policies and strategies to reduce air pollution. The inquiry will complement the work of the National Environment Protection Council, which is developing a national environment protection measure for ambient air quality.

The report is expected to be received in about 12 months; it is a one-year project. I am confident that out of it will come practical ideas to improve the air quality in our urban environment, particularly in those major cities that have been suffering so badly on occasions in the past.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is again addressed to Senator Short. Minister, are you aware that the value of your 6,679 ANZ shares has increased by over $8,000—as of last night—since the time you became the Assistant Treasurer? Would it not be true to say that this increase is in part attributable to market expectations of the future profits to be made by banks, including the ANZ, from their ability to offer RSAs, for which you have direct ministerial responsibility?

—Perhaps we could have a separate discussion, Senator Sherry, on how the share market works. Shares go up and shares go down. Markets go up and markets go down. If you are for one moment suggesting that the policy decision taken by the now government six years ago to introduce RSAs has been responsible for the movements in the share price of the ANZ, or any other bank, life offices, credit unions or building societies over the last six months, I find it an extraordinarily unbelievable and naive assertion. If Senator Sherry is suggesting that the price of ANZ shares in the share market has gone one way or the other on the basis of discussions that the government has been having with a range of financial institutions in relation to the implementation of RSAs, then that is a very sick joke which has not an ounce of substance in it. Senator Sherry well knows that.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Short, why didn't you consider it appropriate to sell your shares in ANZ and other public companies yet Senator Parer did? Why is it that Senator Parer considered that he had a potential conflict of interest and you did not? Why is it that Mr Anderson was required to divest himself of his shareholdings months ago and you were not?

—As I have said today, and as the Prime Minister has said in the other place today, I accept the view that the retention of my shareholding in the ANZ Bank could well be perceived or construed as a breach of the guidelines. It is a totally different issue from the question of conflict of interest. There is no conflict of interest involved in this issue. I accept that there is a perceived breach of the guidelines—I freely acknowledge that—and I have taken steps today to remove that perception by divesting myself of the shares.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment. Minister, I draw your attention to your statement of reasons for the approval of the Port Hinchinbrook resort. In paragraph 81 you indicate that Mr Williams told you that he would not consider any reduction in the size of the resort. I ask you: first, were you not aware that Mr Williams has on many previous occasions made similar assertions in order to pressure government at all levels; second, did you succumb to this pressure from Mr Williams, or how else can we interpret the reasons you have given; third, why did you not insist on a more environmentally appropriate development; fourth, why did you consider it necessary to give equal value to commercial and economic reasons when your responsibilities are to protect world heritage values; and, fifth, are you the Minister for the Environment or are you not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very proud to be the environment minister, Senator Woodley.
—Not for long, not unless you lift your game.

—I hope for a long time, Senator Faulkner, and I am relatively confident that I will do a lot better than you—but that is another story. As you know, Senator Woodley, I have published the statement of reasons for the decisions that I made. It is the oldest trick in the book to selectively quote one paragraph from some 50-odd pages to try to prove a political point. It would be unwise of me, according to the usual practice, to debate those reasons in this place when they are currently before the courts.

ANSWER.PARA: But just for your help, Senator Woodley, I will draw your attention to one of the paragraphs of that document, seeing that you want to selectively quote to suit your purposes. I go to paragraph 53 and I remind you that under section 10, not section 9, of the World Heritage Act and for purposes of the AHC Act I did consider economic and commercial considerations and, as I said in paragraph 53, I gave such considerations relatively little weight.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to Senator Short. Minister, why has it taken until today for you to decide that you will divest yourself of your ANZ shareholding? Why did you consider that you were in breach of the PM's code of conduct today but were not over six months ago, particularly as the Prime Minister has said in question time today that you were in breach of those guidelines?
—I think I have answered that question at least four times today, and I have nothing more to add.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Why have you been in breach of the Senate's resolution regarding the registration of senators' interests for over two years by not informing the committee within 28 days of the disposal of shares in Bridge Oil, which was taken over by Parker and Paisley Petroleum in July 1994 and does not trade any more?

—I would need to check on that. But I think the answer to Senator Sherry's question—which I do not think is a supplementary—is that, from memory, Bridge was taken over on a compulsory acquisition by another company, and it might have been Parker. So I did not sell the shares; they were just disposed of as part of a compulsory acquisition.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Can the minister inform the Senate of the steps he has taken to accelerate Telstra's introduction of advanced telecommunications services and to ensure that those Australians living in non-metropolitan areas are not disadvantaged in the accessing of these services?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —This is actually a very important question because the extent to which people in rural and remote areas have access to services is obviously critical if they are not to be left behind in keeping up with the latest technologies. Before we came to office, Labor had simply allowed what is called the future mode of operation, the roll‐out of digital exchanges, to limp along past the year 2000.

ANSWER.PARA: As a result of discussions we have had with Telstra, they are now committed to the effective completion of that roll‐out program by December 1998. That will mean that Telstra will be able to provide many enhanced services to customers served through a digital exchange including call diversion, call waiting, e-mail, caller line identification—all very important enhanced services. Furthermore, by December 1997 the digitisation rate—in other words, the percentage of total exchanges which will be converted to digital—will be the same in metropolitan as in country areas: 85 five per cent. That is, of course, very good news for those in non-metropolitan areas after years of neglect by Labor.

PARA.BREAK: There is more good news because, from July 1997, 93.4 per cent of customers will be able to obtain an ISDN service within 90 days of request. That will mean that both business and domestic users will be able to dial up fast digital connections as easily as making a phone call. Those sorts of new services will include multiple phones and faxes on the same line; much faster access to fax machines; fast EFTPOS links; fast access to the Internet for educational, cultural and information services; small-screen video confer encing; shared screens; and virtual production groups, so that people in different locations can collaborate and produce high fidelity sound and fast text and graphics.

ANSWER.PARA: All of these will be available only because of the actions that the government has taken. In many countries areas they do not even get the speed that the normal telephone service delivers to people in metropolitan areas of 28.8 kilobytes per second. In some areas they are down around the level of 3 kilobytes per second. As a result of the introduction of ISDN, you will have 64 kilobytes per second. Indeed, on the two lines that are available, that can be conformed so that you get 128 kilobytes per second.

Of course, that will be an enormous advantage for those people in rural areas who are wanting to get access to the Internet for a whole range of reasons, commercial and educational. Farmers will find it of great use to be able to tap in for weather reports, for changes in commodity prices and for the latest research on farming programs. Students living outside the metropolitan areas will also have enormous opportunities to get access. They will not have to wait forever, as is often the case now.

One of the principal things that put people off using the Internet, as Senator Patterson, Senator Hill and I discovered recently, is the enormous amount of time that it can take for downloading, and particularly for graphics to come up on the screen. That is a function of the speed of the system and that is why an ISDN link, and a number of the other technologies that will be much more readily available, will make a huge difference to people who would otherwise have had to languish under Labor's previous approach.

Telstra is also actively pursuing options to use emerging technology to provide similar digital and ISDN services to those who are living more than five kilometres beyond an exchange. Similarly, for those who are on digital remote concentrator systems, there will be other improvements that Telstra and others will be wanting to introduce as quickly as possible. We are doing what Labor never contemplated doing. Indeed, I can remember Michael Lee running scare campaigns and suggesting that this was going to cost billions of dollars. I was delighted that Senator Schacht, by his inaction, effectively endorsed this initiative when we released it recently and I am therefore glad that we have bipartisan support.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday in question time, I undertook to get some further particulars for Senator Neal to a question she asked. I seek leave to have them incorporated in Hansard .

QUESTION.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

I refer the minister to the three 5.1 per cent increases in health insurance premiums put forward by the National Mutual subsidiaries. How many further applications for insurance premium rises are pending; and is it not a fact that the health insurance rebates are now practically worthless as a result of these premium increases?

I ask a supplementary question. I am a little disappointed that the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services is unable to answer on an issue which is of such fundamental importance to a large number in the Australian community. But while she is asking the minister the answer to the previous question, firstly, could she also find out from the minister what the net worth of the rebate will be in light of the premium increases in private health insurance since the budget; and, secondly, could the minister tell us what increased percentage participation in private health insurance is anticipated to come about annually as a result of the private health insurance rebates?
There are at present three notifications by health insurance funds of proposed rule changes increasing premiums under consideration by the Government.

The health insurance incentives are worth exactly as much as they were before the premium increases: up to $450 a year for families, $250 for couples and $125 for singles. As the premium increases would have occurred anyway, people receiving the incentives will still be up to $450 a year better off than they would have been in the absence of the incentives.
The `net worth' of the incentives will thus be up to $450 a year for families, $250 for couples and $125 for singles.

It is estimated that in the absence of the incentives the private health insurance participation rate would have fallen to around 31 per cent by July 1997. It is estimated that the announcement of the incentives will slow the rate of decline, resulting in a participation rate of 32 per cent by July 1997. The incentives are estimated to increase the participation rate by 2 percentage points through the 1997‐98 financial year. Together with the estimated impact of the Medicare surcharge for uninsured high income earners, the participation rate at the end of the 1997‐98 financial year is estimated to be 35.5 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek an explanation from the Minister for Communications and the Arts, Senator Alston, as to why there has been no answer to my question on 23 August, nearly two months ago, regarding the erection of a telecommunications aerial three kilometres north‐east of Mount Donaldson in the Tarkine wilderness of north‐west Tasmania. The question sought an answer from the minister as to what was the purpose of the installation and why it was erected in that area; whether the minister was aware that the area was on the interim list of the National Estate in the Tarkine wilderness; whether the Australian Heritage Commission was advised of the proposal to establish a facility and what was its response; and whether the minister properly sought an environmental impact assessment before the erection of this tower in this very fragile and important area was given the go ahead.

—I will obviously not address the merits of the issues. Let me simply say that I am not aware of that question having come across my desk for approval. I have certainly signed off on a number of other questions. If it is outside the normal 30‐day period, as it appears to be, then I will certainly make inquiries as soon as I get back to ensure that we can get a prompt response for you. The practice in this place has been, traditionally, to contact ministers' offices and inquire whether indeed there is any good reason for the delay. I am not aware whether you have done that in this instance—it has not been brought to my attention. Certainly, I will do whatever I can to expedite that answer being made available.
—I ask that the Senate take note of that explanation.
—It is in the Hansard , Senator. Order! Senator Brown, I understood you to ask that the matter be noted.
—Yes, and I am asking that his explanation be noted.
—His explanation is noted and it is in the Hansard . Are you moving to take note of the answer of Senator Alston?
— Yes, I am.

—I think it may be reasonable at an appropriate time for Senator Brown to move to take note of that explanation. I submit to you, Madam President, that it is now appropriate for the Senate to deal with noting answers to questions given by ministers during question time today. I ask Senator Brown to address that matter after that is concluded. I think that is reasonable.

—Order! Senator Faulkner, under standing order 16, at this stage Senator Brown is entitled to move to take note of that answer just given by Senator Alston and he does not need leave to do so, but it does not intrude on or take any of the half‐hour available for taking note of answers to questions. It is not intruding on the next item on the Notice Paper . Senator Brown, are you seeking to move to take note of that answer?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I am. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the explanation.

I will be very brief. My office contacted Senator Alston's office repeatedly on this matter. It is simply a failure of the minister's office and his control of that office that have led to the matter not being brought to his notice. It is a very important matter as far as I am concerned. It involves the Tarkine wilderness, which is the largest area of unprotected wilderness in south‐east Australia, and it involves the minister giving the go‐ahead for a telecommunications tower in the centre of that wilderness. I note that the minister has now said that he will be very swift in getting a response to the question and I look forward to getting that response within the next few days.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply report to the Senate that my office advises me that a member of staff was contacted by Senator Brown at about 12.30 today. He asked about the progress of the matter. There was no indication given that the matter would be pursued today in question time or afterwards. On that basis, my office undertook to look into the matter, as we are doing now. Had they been aware that you were wanting to raise it today, obviously they would have made me aware in due course. There was certainly no intention to do other than investigate the matter as quickly as possible and we will do that.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of answers given by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Short) to questions without notice asked by Senators Faulkner and Sherry today, relating to senators' interests and the Prime Minister's Guide on Key Elements of Ministerial Responsibility.

I want to say at the outset that we have in the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Short, a minister who has had a most ignominious and inglorious ministerial career. From the time he was appointed Assistant Treasurer he has failed to be able to answer questions as the government's Treasury spokesman in this chamber. He has failed to be coherent on any of the issues that have been directed to him.

From the very start this minister has stumbled and bumbled and fumbled his way through even Dorothy Dix questions. This minister is even incapable of answering Dorothy Dix questions. He has no idea of the basic economic indicators. He has no idea of government revenue measures.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, on a point of order: the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate has actually moved to take note of answers given by Senator Short today. In the first two minutes of his contribution in this debate he has not referred to any of those answers whatsoever. I know, Mr Deputy President, that during this debate in taking note you do allow flexibility as to the relevance of standing orders.
—Nice try but it won't work.
—Do you want to be Deputy President, do you, Bob?
—I actually don't want to be Deputy President.

—Good. The point of order, if I may proceed with it, is that Senator Faulkner should be asked to address at least some of his comments in this debate to the answers provided by Senator Short during question time today. There should be some scintilla of relevance.
—Senator Faulkner has been going for less than one minute. I think we should hear a little more of what he is saying before we make any decision about that.

—This is a minister, I recall, who got so tangled up in the Sales Tax Assessment Act that I was forced to put out a media release headed `Senator Jim Short: when will the incompetence end?'. The answer to that question is never—never will the incompetence of this minister end. Today is absolute proof that this minister is not up to the job. Other ministers, other responsible ministers, have divested themselves of their shareholdings because of conflicts of interest—
—When they got caught out.

—When they have been caught out. Of course, Senator Short has learnt nothing from that—nothing at all. This is an absolutely clear breach of Mr Howard's ministerial code. There are no excuses for Senator Short's behaviour.

BREAK.PARA: The fact is that Senator Short has owned up until today nearly 7,000 ANZ shares. His explanation to the Senate today after he had been caught out by the Labor opposition was to say that he is going to direct his broker to divest of them today. Of course he should have done that as soon as he had been commissioned as Assistant Treasurer in April because in that role he is directly responsible in the government of Australia for banking and superannuation matters. This is a clear conflict of interest. There is no question that he has been involved in high level discussions and has helped make decisions. There is a clear conflict of interest.

This issue goes right to the heart of probity in government. It goes right to the issue of integrity. This is beyond incompetence. This is beyond the fact that Senator Short is a failure. We know that Senator Short is not up to the job. We know that he should not have been appointed minister, but we have a situation today when Mr Howard said in the House of Representatives, `I regret very much the Assistant Treasurer's handling of this matter.' Mr Howard regrets it.

Senator Hill would not cut the Assistant Treasurer loose. I gave him ample opportunity during question time to support that. He said on two occasions that he didn't regret the Assistant Treasurer's handling of this matter. You ought to get your lines right, Senator Hill. Quite clearly, this minister has been exposed by the Labor Party as having a conflict of interest. He has done the wrong thing for a long period of time and he has been caught out red‐handed by Labor.

Will Mr Howard do the right thing and sack him, as he should? This is a minister who has breached the Prime Minister's ministerial code of conduct. Who can forget Mr Howard, puffed up with all his self‐importance, his bombast and pomposity, saying, `This will be a government of probity. This will be a government that cares about ministerial responsibility. This will be a government that cares about the importance of parliamentary process.' This minister has failed on all counts. Senator Short is a failure. Mr Howard has not committed himself to his own standards of ministerial responsibility. This minister should be sacked.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we have had a very shameful and grubby attack by this disgusting opposition on one of our most dignified and distinguished members of the ministry. Therefore, it gives me a great deal of pleasure to rise in support of my colleague Senator Short.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Short has an expertise that is not in the opposition and is second to none in the financial field. He has an outstanding record of achievement. It grieves me very much to hear the sorts of comments coming out of the mouths of such people as Senator Sherry and the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Faulkner).

After 13 years of Labor's mismanagement, Australia desperately needs the expertise that Senator Short brings to this portfolio. What is your agenda? A grubby exercise to try to get rid of him. You have failed now and you will fail in the future.

Integrity and decency have been the hallmarks of Senator Short's whole career and his participation in this Senate. This expertise has been achieved over many years. He has applied remarkable intellect and assiduous hard work to one of the most difficult tasks that this country faces—it is facing it because of the neglect and mismanagement of the former government.

In his early years in the Treasury, he rose very quickly to senior responsibility. Between 1967 and 1970, he held the important position of Treasury representative in London, where he was held in very high regard for his competency and his integrity. Between 1971 and 1975, he held two high level positions: Assistant Secretary in the Overseas Economic Relations Division and Assistant Secretary in the Foreign Investment Division of Treasury.

To hear the rubbish coming from the opposition alleging incompetence just does not fit with the facts. Members of the opposition are not interested in the facts. They are not interested in the truth. They are trying to impugn things that are just not there. What we have heard today are long bows and minuscule perceptions leading to incorrect conclusions. The manner of the questioning was quite disgraceful.

On entering the federal parliament as the member for Ballarat, he immediately took up positions on the Joint Statutory Committee of Public Accounts. He was also a member of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. He discharged his responsibility with great dignity. Following his defeat in the election in 1980, he became General Manager, Corporate Affairs, of ACI International, a position which very suitably equipped him for service in the area of government.

During his time in the Senate, he has held a number of responsible positions where his informed contribution, especially in finance, has been of great benefit to this nation. That should be put on the public record. These include being the spokesman on finance and Deputy Leader of the Opposition. His outstanding ability to grasp the complexities of economic issues is an invaluable asset not just to the government but, I put to you, to the whole of Australia and all Australians.

It is indeed true that he has had a share portfolio, but what is the shame in that? He has acknowledged this and his record is on the register. The grubby manner in which they go through these registers to pick out long bows and inaccuracies and come to incorrect conclusions I think is disgraceful. He has held high‐level positions in a large multinational company. Naturally, you would expect a man who has a considerable achievement to have built up some share portfolio interests.

It is noted that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Senator Sherry) has backtracked on his allegations of impropriety in this field, and so he should. I believe what he has put forward today is quite mischievous and the manner in which he has brought it to the press brings no honour or credit to Senator Sherry.

This morning the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Short) assured the Senate that he is not a share trader. That is the important point—he is not there to make money. After all, what would his interest in that portfolio have on one of the largest companies in Australia? It would be absolutely minuscule. We have to look at the materiality of events. When you start talking about materiality and people benefiting from the office, I ask you to look at the record of your previous Prime Minister. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not sure whether that was a valedictory or an obituary for Senator Short. Senator Watson outlined his so-called magnificent record. If there is something that is going to appear on Senator Short's record as of today, it will be the $8,000 profit he makes today as a result of selling his ANZ shares that he should have sold six months ago.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us turn to the ministerial guidelines that the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, laid down for ministers on your side to observe. It says:

Ministers are required to divest themselves of all shares and similar interests in any company or business involved in the area of their portfolio responsibilities. The transfer of interests to a family member or to a nominee or trust is not an acceptable form of divestment.
Senator Short has shareholdings in some 15 companies. Senator Gibson, who has got off very lightly in this debate, has shareholdings in some 13 companies.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The guidelines do apply to parliamentary secretaries—you had better go and read them if you ever want to be one. In terms of Senator Short's and Senator Gibson's responsibilities, Senator Short had specific responsibility back in April for insurance and superannuation and he has specific responsibility for administration of the banking laws—quite specific responsibility. He has been involved in policy development. He partly admitted it today. Although, when we pressed him about whether he had declared his interest at cabinet meetings, he would not own up and he would not tell us what he had done.

SPEECH.PARA: But he had a very clear conflict of interest—shareholdings in ANZ and responsibility for the administration of banking and superannuation in respect of RSAs and banks. Absolute conflict of interest! There is no doubt that there is a conflict of interest. What is amazing is that Senator Short still will not admit that he had a conflict of interest. He cannot see that he has a conflict of interest.

What did the Prime Minister say about Senator Short today? `I deeply regret the Assistant Treasurer's handling of this matter.' He went on and said that you did have a conflict of interest. Why did not Senator Short dispose of these shares six months ago? We have already been through a number of episodes with Mr Anderson and Senator Herron.

TALK.START.PARA: —His surgery.

—His surgery, not shares in this case. Why did not Senator Short at that stage recognise that he had a conflict of interest? No, Senator Short believes he can hold 6,670-odd shares in ANZ—not a small holding. He has almost 7,000 shares, which will be sold today at a profit of over $8,000. So Senator Short—having been caught out and called to order by Labor, which looked at the pecuniary interest register—makes a profit out of selling his shares. He is going to make $8,000, and that is an outrageous position that Senator Short has adopted.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Short also has a range of shareholdings in other companies. I put this to Senator Short and Senator Gibson: when they are involved in economic decision making in this government—whether it is budget preparation or ERC, as is Senator Short's position, whether they are involved in discussions with the stock market or ASX, or whether they are involved in discussions with other economic commentators—they are going to have to ask themselves, `Is there a conflict of interest in respect of my shareholdings?'

Let us look have a look at them. They include: BHP, CRA, CSR, Boral, Bridge Oil—and Senator Short did not know it disappeared two years ago; he could not even keep up with that much—Pasminco, Jennings Industries, Centro Properties, Mirvac, AGL, Cornwell Resources, Valero Energy and Parlawick Pty Ltd. I put it to the Senate that Senator Short, even when he disposes of these ANZ shares today at a profit of over $8,000, having been caught—

TALK.START.PARA: —Big deal!

—If he had sold them six months ago, Senator, he would not have made an $8,000 profit. That is when he should have sold the shares. The fact is that Senator Short has inside knowledge of the operation and the way economic decisions are taken. Every time something happens that relates to one of these shareholdings, we will remind you of it.

—I would like to comment on a few of the things Senator Sherry just told us. Firstly, I will start with what he said about Senator Herron. He mentioned that we have had discussions about Senator Herron. I cannot remember discussions in this place—and I do not miss many sittings of parliament—about Senator Herron's shares. Senator Herron did say that he wished he had some. I suggest that Senator Sherry should apologise to him for a start.
—He has only got a scalpel.
—Order! Senator Collins, if you want to be disorderly, sit in your seat.

—So I think Senator Sherry owes Senator Herron an apology. There is another point I would like to address. I have not asked Senator Short the details of his portfolio, but I did hear Senator Sherry say—correct me if I am wrong—that Senator Short had shares in 15 other companies. Is that right, Senator Sherry?
—It would be disorderly to respond to your question.

—Correct me if I am wrong, but I think Senator Sherry said that Senator Short had shares in 15 other companies. He also said that Senator Short made $8,000 profit today by selling his own ANZ shares. If Senator Short has to dispose of his ANZ shares today, I presume that he is disposing of his shares in the 15 other companies.
—No, he is not actually.

—Yes. If he is disposing of shares in one company, he is disposing of shares in the others. How can you tell me that he is going to finish up with a profit at the end of the day? How do you know he made $8,000 on the ANZ shares? I presume he is selling the rest of the shares to comply with the Prime Minister's orders. You do not know until the wash up comes how much profit he will make.
—If I get into trouble, please don't try to help me out.

—Yes. Also, if Senator Sherry considers that $8,000 is a big profit, I am just wondering what Senator Sherry has been doing all his life. I say this to Senator Sherry: before you fly off and accuse people like Senator Herron of having shares and this fellow here, Senator Short, of making an $8,000 profit, wait until the whole portfolio is added up and see how much profit there is at the end of the day. If there is any more than that, we will all know about it and I will be the first to apologise. The point is: I want to see before you make that statement how much the profit is actually going to be. Senator Collins, you were a cabinet minister once, weren't you?
—Without a share to my name.
—All right. If you had 10 companies, you would not only have to sell shares in one company to satisfy the regulation, you would have to sell the lot.
—I agree.

—Yes. So I presume it is the same story with him. You have to wait until you have worked out the bottom line. When you get the cheque from the stockbroker with all of those deductions, then, of course, you will see whether he is liable for some tax as well. We will see whether he finishes up in front. We will carry that argument on later if he is indeed in front.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Panizza comes here not to praise Senator Short but to bury him. Isn't it significant that Senator Hill has not risen to his feet to defend his ministerial colleague? When this whole issue is examined, in the end people will dismiss Senator Short as a befuddled fool who probably did not try to breach the guidelines but was ignorant of them.

SPEECH.PARA: The real fault here lies with the Prime Minister in John Howard. Let us go back to the system that is put in place to make sure that prime ministerial guidelines cannot be breached. The Prime Minister in the parliament put down the guidelines on ministerial behaviour. Today in the House of Representatives he confirmed that Senator Short was in breach of those guidelines. He said he was in breach. He also said that last night he did consider whether to dismiss Senator Short. He decided against that because, and I seek to paraphrase only, he did not see—

TALK.START.PARA: —Inadvertently.

—It was a hanging fence and, as Senator Collins interjects, this may have been inadvertent. That may be true, but why did the Prime Minister set up these guidelines, set up a system where ministers declare not only their shareholdings but the value of their shareholdings, the value of their debts? I assume that all that material was put in in time, by 27 May, across to the Prime Minister. The responsibility for examining that confidential material rests with the Prime Minister so that he can determine whether there will be any future potential conflict of interest.

SPEECH.PARA: That is where the weakness is. Do we have a lazy Prime Minister who did not bother to go through the 27 declarations from ministers and the 10 from parliamentary secretaries? Did the Prime Minister delegate that to a staff member? Was there a failure at that particular level? It is quite clear from the very statements and answers today that Senator Short still does not concede properly that there was a breach of the guidelines. He goes back to the fact that he does not believe that, in his past record—I believe him over this part—any of his decisions in government were influenced by his shareholdings. That is not the point: the point is that Senator Short continued to own these shares—in a very sensitive area that he had direct responsibility for—for six months. It was the Prime Minister's responsibility to draw this to Senator Short's attention and ask him to dispose of the shares.

There is nothing new in this, because we know that, on 20 March, Senator Parer—either at a profit or a loss; I will not speculate either way—sold his shares in mining companies so that there would not be a conflict of interest. As well as that, we know that Mr Anderson sold his shares so that there would not be a conflict of interest. It is all very well for Senator Panizza to volunteer here today that Senator Short is going to sell all the rest of his shares. With due respect, that ain't on the record anywhere. It has not been said—you presumed it. Senator Short said today that he would sell his ANZ shares. The point about the profit from those shares is that it is not the profit from when Senator Short bought the shares to when he sells the shares, but the profit from when he should have sold the shares until today.

Here we are—we must be the great mugs of the world. We expose the conflict of interest, we shame the Prime Minister into directing Senator Short to sell the shares—and what happens? He is nine grand better off! He is $9,000 better off. He should donate that to charity or somewhere else.
