SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop, Sen Mark

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few comments in respect of the motion that is currently before us. I want to go right back to the beginning of this process, the Senate's finance and public administration committee dealing with estimates. That was a very useful exercise we went through as we participated in the discussion of that committee.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the very early observations I made as I watched the committee go about its activity was that Senator Ian Macdonald took a very relaxed, almost disinterested, attitude to the deliberations of the committee and the questions that were asked at that committee. He was relaxed, leaning back and not greatly interested in the process at all.

I had presumed that the purpose of that committee was to do some program analysis, some financial analysis, some questioning of the departmental officials and to gain some useful information for our deliberations later. I was very surprised as Senator Ray engaged in a process of examination of the minister and a number of departmental officials who were involved in this process of awarding the tender.

What I was most interested in as the discussion pursued was how Senator Macdonald became agitated and for the first time in three days became very interested in the deliberations of the committee and attempted to raise a number of red herrings, as he has pursued in this debate today in reference to Senator Richardson, Mr Singleton and past contracts awarded by the previous government. But his manner, his demeanour, changed as Senator Ray pursued his particular avenue and, indeed, gained a lot of interesting information about the process of awarding the tender in this particular issue.

Let us look at the information that has been put before us today. Let us review the tender process, the decision making of the relevant parties and the consequences that need to be visited upon a number of those persons. Firstly, let us turn to the motion itself. The motion put forward by Senator Bolkus notes:

PARA.TAB: (i) the awarding of an advertising contract to DDB Needham, Adelaide, in spite of its being rated fifth on the qualitative polling done for the Government by Elliott and Shanahan,
(ii) that Mr Ted Horton, Mr John King and Mr Toby Ralph, principals of DDB Needham, were key advertising advisers to the Liberal Party during the 1996 federal election campaign,

(iii) that the ministerial committee to determine these matters included the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister (Senator Minchin), Mr Grahame Morris and Mr Petro Georgiou, all of whom, in their previous capacities as State Directors of the Liberal Party in either South Australia or Victoria, had contracted with DDB Needham for that firm to perform work on behalf of the Liberal Party, and
(iv) that none of the above declared that there was a conflict of interest in awarding the contract; and

SPEECH.PARA: (b) calls on the Government to set up an independent judicial inquiry into the tendering process and related matters.

The motion raises serious issues of principle and it needs proper and reasoned consideration. So let us go through that process: first, the review of the tender process; secondly, the decision making of the relevant parties; and, thirdly, the consequences for the relevant participants.

As has been outlined and not seriously disputed by the government, it is relatively clear what occurred. The government, in its wisdom, made a decision to conduct an advertising campaign arising out of the terrible events at Port Arthur. There was nothing wrong with that. It sought voluntary compliance with its future gun legislation and allocated something in the order of $2 million for all communication activities.

The brief that was sent out to the advertising agencies sought voluntary compliance. It sought that the public be informed which guns, rifles, et cetera, were barred and which of those guns or rifles had restricted activities. It sought to influence the community so that the community surrendered its firearms. The brief, as I understand it, as customary practice, invited 200 advertising firms to tender. Those firms' names were maintained on a public register. The first point, as we understand it, was that DDB was not on that register; it was added later.

On 5 August, after reviewing submissions, five firms were asked to submit. All of those bids were submitted for market testing in a range of areas and occupations of both genders in metropolitan and rural areas across the nation. It was a very wide testing exercise that the government sought on the five bids.

The pitch that was put by DDB Needham we were told by OGIA was `Gun control: It's Time to Bite the Bullet'. This particular pitch was not received well. The test groups comprising the focus groups found it negative, discouraging and offensive. OGIA's evaluation was that the DDB brief barely matched the terms of reference. They did not meet the demands of the brief. They were difficult to assess. It generated considerable anger. It was seen as dictatorial, and the research showed that gun owners rejected the idea of the campaign. On the advice of the evaluation department, the DDB brief was poorly put together, contrary to the purpose of the government and tested badly.

OGIA, the Office of Government Information and Advertising, also tested the other briefs. What emerged is also clear and on the public record from the estimates committee. The information in a range of the other briefs was very clear. There was widespread approval by the focus groups. The Bevins brief was determined to be superior. It had strong branding and a positive response. It did not confuse and it generated interest and impact. The participants said the Bevins brief was down to earth and its pitch clear. So the focus groups, as reported by OGIA in their evaluation to the estimates committee, gave virtually zero out of 100 to the DDB brief and very high marks to the other briefs, in particular the Bevins brief.

In late August a ministerial committee was established. We were told, as I recall, at the estimates committee that two tenders were short‐listed. Senator Abetz made some comments on that, and I will return to that later. A week later, on 2 September, the short list was increased to three. The third firm, being the eventual successor, was the firm which had been rated most poorly by the evaluation agency. We were told today that Mr Morris, chief political adviser to the Prime Minister, insisted upon the DDB brief being included and the number being increased to three.

Let us now turn to the decision making process and the participants in that process—the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Jull); Senator Minchin; Mr Georgiou; Mr Grahame Morris, the chief political adviser to the Prime Minister, Mr Howard; and an adviser to the Attorney-General, Mr Williams. We were told there were also other state ministers and their advisers present—Mr Whelan from New South Wales and Mr Humphries and their advisers in an advisory capacity but not in a voting capacity. A number of staff from OGIA and other agencies were also present.

The meeting, we were told, kicked off around about 5.30 p.m. It adjourned for dinner and a decision was anticipated to be made after dinner. Around about 9.30 p.m. there was a break and Bevins was informed that the final decision was being vociferously debated. Bevins's poor prospects were nothing to do with the quality of its work and it was indicated that its brief would be unsuccessful.

Then we come to the interesting part of the evening, as outlined by Senator Bolkus and Senator Robert Ray. Around about 10.30 p.m. it was thought that the deliberations should be concluded. Public servants were asked to leave. The note taking process ceased, no minutes were kept, no records were taken and no independent witnesses were available.

Around about 11 p.m. before the vote, Mr Whelan from New South Wales left the meeting to return to his home. What we know occurred after that was that DDB was given the contract. It had the poorest rating from OGIA. It had the last ranking of fifth out of five. It was short‐listed at the request of Mr Morris, but it was given the job and the revenues at around about 12.10 p.m.

The aftermath, according to the West Australian newspaper, is relatively clear. Three of the five persons who participated—and I will not repeat the details, because they were outlined by Senator Robert Ray—apparently voted for another firm, not for DDB. But, as we now know and as was explained at the estimates committee, the DDB firm gained the contract.

That firm has been engaged in extensive work for the Liberal Party over a number of years in South Australia, Victoria and at a national level. Indeed, I must concur with what Senator Robert Ray said. I do not have any particular problem with advertising agencies, professional firms, legal accounting or whatever gaining work from governments or political parties. The only caveat I would offer is that the process needs to be clear, it needs to be transparent, it needs to be noted and it needs to be capable of independent verification.

BREAK.PARA: So the complaint is not that the contract was awarded to the DDB firm; the complaint and the nature of this debate is about the process of awarding that contract. It seems to me, looking on from the outside, that there was a degree of chicanery and a degree of improper involvement, and a decision that is improper. I do not share Senator Robert Ray's view that it is the greatest political rort of the last 15 years or the greatest political rort of all time. It strikes me as being mean, pithy and a very poor effort. I suggest that those who were involved in the decision making process should have disqualified themselves; they should not have participated.

The next thing we are aware of is that the size of the contract increased from the original amount of $1 million or $2 million to over $3 million by a decision of cabinet on or around 24 September. What are the consequences of this decision making process and the awarding of the contract? We know that the advertising campaign has been delayed. It is non-existent in a number of states. Even though the campaign is non-existent in those states—it has not been run, it is not currently being run and, apparently, there is no intention to run it in the immediate future—the guns are still being surrendered.

Why has this occurred? As it was explained today—and not rebutted by Senator Macdonald or Senator Abetz—DDB was not ready. It was not able to give effect to the large contract that had been awarded to its firm. So the original campaign by DDB was poorly put together; there was little to no merit, as said in the evaluation process; the brief was not completed; and the job has not been delivered.

We send a terrible message to professional organisations, to professional associations and to the advertising industry: we send a message that process is not important. We send a message that corruption in the process is something that is going to be tolerated. It is not the way that we should be engaged in business. It is not the way this government, or any government, should be engaged in the letting of significant contracts.

PARA.BREAK: I would like to turn to the contributions of Senator Macdonald and Senator Abetz. Sena tor Macdonald did not rebut any of the points raised by the prior debaters. He tried to colour the issues, to confuse us by making references to Senator Richardson, to Mr Singleton and to Mr Cameron. He expressly denied any illegal or improper activity on the part of any of those men or their organisations. He expressly denied that. He kept dancing around the sides, hinting at improper behaviour. He then covered himself by saying, `Nothing occurred. I raise nothing. I make no allegations.' He simply sought to confuse the issue.

BREAK.PARA: So it raises what criteria were used to award the contract? What were the criteria that defeated the Bevins firm? We do not know. All we know is that a decision was made. What was the mistake of Mr Bevins? He was not involved with the Liberal Party. That was his mistake. He had no influence in the decision making process. His submission had a lot of merit. It was the best submission. His fault, his mistake, was that he had no influence. He had no contacts. He had a lot of merit, a lot of hard work and a lot of skill, but no influence.

So we should now turn in that context to the contribution of Senator Abetz. Senator Abetz made nine points in his submission. Firstly, he made some references to trade unions and members of parliament who were formerly union officials, and he suggested they should disqualify themselves from participation in this debate. How that related to the motion, he did not explain. It was a gratuitous aside.

His second point—and it seems to be a feature in his debating style—was that he referred to the report by Gary Gray after the last federal election. That report, of course, was a report to members of the Australian Labor Party as to why we lost the election. It bore no relationship to the motion before us, to the awarding of the contract, but it is worth while to throw into the debate.

His third point was that he chose to misunderstand or misinterpret the significance of paragraph (ii) in the motion. His fourth point was an arcane legal point as to the legal status of the Liberal Party and its agents at law in terms of the signing of documents. Once again, one asks how that relates to the motion before us.

His fifth point was Mr Grahame Morris's role and his apparent responsibility for the temporary high standing of the Prime Minister in the polls. His sixth point was some off-the-cuff reference by former Senator Gareth Evans, and he thought it was so worth while that he repeated it five times.

His seventh point was commercial benefit to persons individually in paragraph (iv). He made reference to the selection panel. My memory of the evidence at the estimates committee was that two firms were short-listed, that it was the advice of the officer from OGIA that it was not three—that the third firm, the firm that eventually gained the contract, was added at a later time. Finally, Senator Abetz gave us his assessment of Senator Bolkus's character. How any of that related to the issue under discussion escapes me. None of it addressed the merit of the motion.

So, in summing up, it appears that there has been a degree of impropriety in the process of awarding this contract. It involves senior members of the government and officials of the staff of the Prime Minister. There is conflicting advice given to the Senate via the estimates committee and in the contributions today as to what actually occurred. There is certainly enough evidence put before the Senate today to suggest that an inquiry is needed to establish what the facts were, what the facts are—indeed to review this entire process. So I would urge the passage of this motion before us today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —During this afternoon, having examined this debate, I have come to the conclusion that the opposition may well be right. There may, in fact, be a conflict of interest in this matter, but it is not the conflict of interest alleged by those opposite. I will explain to the Senate why, in fact, there is a prima-facie conflict of interest and where that conflict of interest lies. When I have concluded, the silence on the other side of the chamber will be deafening.

SPEECH.PARA: The opposition has made a large amount of political capital out of a report prepared by the Office of Government Information and Advertising, and they have quoted from that report very selectively. But what they may not have known—or maybe they knew and withheld it from this Senate; that, in itself, would be a shameful act—is that it is our understanding that one of the principal authors of the report prepared by the Office of Government Information and Advertising has, in fact, been offered a lucrative position with Bevins advertising agency: the very advertising agency which that mob on the other side claims should have this contract. That is the apparent conflict of interest. It is not a conflict of interest that affects Senator Minchin, it is not a conflict of interest that affects Mr Georgiou, nor is it a conflict of interest that affects Mr Morris. What we have is an apparent conflict of interest within the government office that prepared the assessment on which the people opposite have relied for over two hours this afternoon as the only substance for their debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Say that outside!
—Look at Senator Cook squealing like a stuck pig on the other side of the chamber. Look at Senator Cook squealing like a stuck pig because he does not like it when the truth is out.

SPEECH.PARA: In the course of the debate earlier on this afternoon Senator Bolkus told us that an officer from the department absented himself from a meeting at 9.30 in the evening and phoned Bevins to say, `You've got a great presentation. I don't think you're going to get it and it has not got anything to do with the quality of the presentation.' Was that officer the same officer who helped prepare this report? Was it the same officer who, we understand, has been offered a very lucrative contract with Bevins? I suspect that the silence from the other side of the chamber now is proof positive that the opposition have been caught out. They came in here wanting a debate on sleaze and wanting to smear people's integrity, and yet the truth is that they did not have the integrity to tell the Senate chamber all that they knew or should have known about this sordid matter.

It is the case now that the minister has asked the secretary to make a report on the whole proceedings of this matter, because it is highly worrying that a government officer would be the principal author of a report recommending an advertising agency which has offered him a very lucrative contract. It would be even more disturbing if an opposition, knowing all these facts, used that report—selectively used that report, as they have this evening—to attempt to smear the good name, the character and the integrity of an honourable senator in this chamber and an honourable member of the other place. That is what the Labor Party have done. They have no intention at all in this debate of having integrity, having a full disclosure, having the truth or having the facts.

The great thing about hypocrisy as far as the opposition are concerned is that you do not have to worry about the facts getting in the way of your prejudices. That is the fact. They do not have to worry about the facts because, if you believe in hypocrisy, you never let facts get in the way of your prejudice. All we have seen tonight has been two hours of prejudice dredged up by the other side and yet the facts are quite contrary to that prejudice. The facts reveal a situation other than that alleged by those who sit on the other side of the chamber.

I believe that those on the other side who spoke earlier and who have accused Senator Minchin and Mr Georgiou of impropriety ought to come into this chamber on the adjournment tonight and apologise. Senator Bolkus ought to come in here and apologise, Senator Ray ought to come in here and apologise, and Senator Bishop should not take a step out of this place. If they do not apologise then they are not men of integrity and they are not men who seek the truth; they are men who will use any device and any opportunity to twist the facts—not to achieve the truth, but for their own grubby political ends. Those who live by the sword die by the sword. And they are dying a gruesome death on the other side of the chamber. What we have here now are the facts. Those facts are very clear and the opposition can have no answer to those facts. That is why they ought to have the decency to apologise and to withdraw the motion currently before the Senate.

We could go on at great length about all the impropriety that occurred when the previous government was in power. When former Senator Richardson was the minister responsible for choosing advertising, the only protection we had against impropriety was that he had two other members on the committee who were not as friendly with Mr Singleton as he was! They were not bosom buddies, but that does not say that they were going to ensure propriety; they just were not as friendly as he was. That was the only standard of propriety that existed when the Labor Party were in government, and now they come in here and want another standard of propriety. And yet, when the truth is brought out and when we say, `Yes, there may have been a conflict of interest, but it wasn't Senator Minchin's conflict of interest and it wasn't Mr Georgiou's conflict of interest,' they squeal like stuck pigs—and so they ought, because a little bit of the truth can be a painful thing.

I know that honourable senators on the other side often can only take a little bit of the truth in each day. It is only in small doses that truth can be allowed to reign on the other side. When they are confronted with the full force of the truth, when they are confronted with the truth in all its glory, what do they do? They squeal and complain and say, `Step out of the chamber.' We have had two hours of the people on the other side in this place alleging the most appallingly defamatory things against an honourable member of this chamber and an honourable member of the other place—and not once did they bother to step outside and say it. And yet, when the truth comes out, they say, `Step outside, step outside, step outside.' When Senator Cook, Senator Ray and Senator Bolkus want to step outside and put their absurd, irrational and thoroughly reprehensible comments to the test in a court of law, we will find them wanting of will.

They have been great heroes for two hours and now they are turning into cowards without conviction because the truth is that every one of the allegations that these people have raised has been utterly spurious. Their only source of information for the speeches we have had from the other side, from what we can gather, was the report prepared by somebody whom we believe to have had a vested financial interest in one advertising company coming out the winner in that process. That advertising company did not come out, so I wonder how it is that the Labor Party became aware of this whole process. Maybe this matter does deserve further investigation but not further investigation in this chamber—further investigation on the proper procedures to ascertain how it was that this shameful debate could have been given any semblance of credibility by the people on the other side and how somebody could have fed them the information which they have used to smear the integrity of two fine people on this side of the chamber.

The opposition ought to hang their heads in shame. They ought to come in here and apologise. They ought to withdraw this ridiculous and shameful motion because, if they do not do those things, then it is clear that the opposition loves to use hypocrisy and loves to use prejudice, but is afraid of the facts and is afraid of what will happen when their spurious allegations are exposed for all to see. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for the consideration of general business having expired, the Senate will proceed to the consideration of committee reports and government responses.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 12 September 1996, on motion by Senator Tambling:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have the report in front of me. I have sent for a copy of it—it has not yet arrived in the chamber—and I want to make a couple of comments about it. As the program shows and as you have rightly described it, this is a government response to the report of the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities dealing with the annual reports of the Australian Securities Commission and other bodies. The Securities Commission has attracted—and does from time to time—critical analysis and appraisal in the popular media as to its effectiveness. Obviously, it does that because, as the watchdog on corporate governance in Australia, it has reposed in it the key responsibility on behalf of taxpayers to ensure that the affairs of the corporate world are run with probity and in compliance with the law. The obligation on the Securities Commission is to detect fraud when and if it occurs and to refer matters to prosecution should there be a case for that.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of white collar crime and corporation corruption, it is a major responsibility and, within its resources, I think the Securities Commission handles its responsibilities with great effectiveness. Nonetheless, what also has to be said is that there are, increasingly, comments about the number of corporate criminals that have been brought to justice in this country and questioning of how effective the ASC is.

It is a matter of public record that only two people have been convicted of insider trading in Australia in the most recent past and that does not seem to accord with marketplace experience of how extensive this practice might be. Indeed, as a consequence of the foreign takeover of TNT, the Australian owned transport company, last week there were quite strong allegations that some inside knowledge of the impending takeover may have governed particular investments in share purchases that resulted in massive windfall gains to those individuals who exercised those share purchases.

If one reads the published information—and I only have access to what is in the media on this—certainly, prima facie, there is a case to say that massive gains were made and that the circumstances in which they were achieved raise reasonable doubt as to whether or not they were done honestly. I am sure that matter is being investigated by the ASC. I mention that only to illustrate the point that there is, behind the comments about corporate criminality, some empirical evidence in the marketplace to suggest or to justify continuing concern about the effectiveness of the ASC.

BREAK.PARA: We recently went through the estimates processes with the ASC and discussed with them at considerable length, as the estimates processes enable us to do, measures that they are taking in order to improve their circumstances. Indeed, my colleague the shadow minister for communications, Chris Schacht, extensively quizzed the ASC and cited the landmark publication The Bold Riders, which is a close history of corporate corruption in Australia with reference particularly to the period in the 1980s when many of the corporate cowboys got away with millions of dollars.

He took the ASC quite carefully through some of the allegations made, to test how their detection and scrutiny processes had benefited from those learning experiences and whether or not those experiences were capable of being created again in Australia. I must say that, while the answers of the ASC were professional and persuasive, nonetheless there still is a nagging doubt as to whether the ASC is as fully equipped as it ought to be to discharge its obligations to the community.

In saying that, and in referring to that nagging doubt, I want to say very clearly and very publicly that that is not to question the professionalism of the officers of this body. Indeed, one would see that those officers, in being questioned in an estimates committee process, in any case have an obligation to defend the integrity of the commission. It is certainly not the purpose of the questioners, in this case, to in any way reflect upon the commission, for fear that that may encourage or embolden actual or potential corporate criminals into believing that they can get away with their nefarious acts.

Faced with those considerations, I have to say that the decision in this current budget to reduce the funding to this body does raise some doubts in my mind as to whether or not the ASC is adequately funded by the government to do the task it has and to shoulder the heavy responsibility that it has before it.

One of the key issues here is that the level of corporate corruption tends to follow in a staged way. We had an outbreak of it in the 1980s. We had evidence in the committee inquiry of the degree and magnitude of it. Quite astonishing fortunes were made. Charges have been preferred against individuals but, because individuals themselves have benefited massively financially from that corruption, they are cashed up and able to engage highly qualified legal counsel who bog down court proceedings for prosecution with endless technicality and delay.

The very wealth they generate by their corruption, if you like, acts as a way of hiring legal armour to prevent them from being, at the end of the day, prosecuted. Certainly, if they are not prosecuted successfully it means that the law has been complied with. But the issue here is whether, in complying with the law, justice has been delivered.

I rise to speak on this paper in order to make the point that I think the government owes the taxpayers of this country—the many thousands of honest business people, men and women, who go about their affairs in the expectation that other business colleagues observe business law properly—an assurance that their interests are properly protected and that the ASC is funded to do its job.

We heard evidence also that the likelihood of one of Australia's most notorious corporate criminals, Christopher Skase, ever being able to be brought to justice in Australia now is so remote as not to be considered a possibility at all. And that is a further illustration of the problem here.

In nub, my point is that, with the current concern being expressed about the degree of corporate criminality, the watchdog that has the responsibility to detect it and refer matters for prosecution over it, and the cost of bringing to justice cashed‐up corporate crooks who are able to hire expensive legal counsel to protect them, are the important issues.

I am not saying in any way that the government is necessarily reducing funds to the ASC in order to make it easier for corporate corruption. Nonetheless, it is very important that the role of the ASC be properly resourced in order to ensure that that corruption does not occur.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 12 September, on motion by Senator Tambling:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on this matter for the reason that I have followed quite closely the Senate committee's investigation of the CSIRO and its subsequent report, CSIRO: the case for revitalisation: administration and funding of rural research . I have to declare to the Senate immediately an interest and why I did that.

SPEECH.PARA: At the time that this Senate inquiry was referred, I was the minister for science, and this inquiry was into—

TALK.START.PARA: —First class.

—Thank you indeed. And this inquiry was into a major entity in the portfolio of science. As a consequence, since it raised issues of whether or not the CSIRO was properly balanced and targeted, to discharge my responsibility as a science minister I followed the affairs of this inquiry quite closely, and, I might say, received criticism as a minister from the then opposition—now the government—for failing, as I think they would term it, to impose upon the CSIRO their version of what the CSIRO should do.

SPEECH.PARA: In my view, the reason this report was originally developed in the Senate is that the CSIRO were rationalising the establishment of their rural research agencies. They were doing this in a number of states, one of which was Western Australia and that excited the interests of some Western Australian senators in the then opposition at the time. Therefore, I took the view that this inquiry arose from special pleading by a sectional interest rather than because of a general concern about the nature and suitability of the administration and vital nature of the CSIRO at the time.

I have to say that the report was more sweeping than that and the report came to a number of conclusions with which I am in hearty concord. It did serve, I think, a useful role at the end of the day. However and nonetheless, the argument remained that I, the minister, should somehow interfere with the CSIRO. I want to deal with that because it touches directly on the matter that is before the chamber.

The CSIRO is a statutory organisation. It is in many respects Australia's premiere science body. It is one of the oldest. It is certainly the grandest of all the science institutions we have in this country. It rightfully and properly enjoys a large reputation for excellence in Australia and has a peerless international reputation as well. I think there is a degree of common view about that. Because it is so large, it has reached so wide and the issues with which it deals are so important, there is also a constant audience of criticism as to whether the CSIRO as a major organisation has all of its settings absolutely right. The first thing the CSIRO would say is that it is absolutely sure it hasn't, but it tries to get them right and works as closely with advisory panels and with community needs and sectional interests as it can in order to do so.

What is also fundamental to this is that the board that governs the CSIRO, which has under its act the statutory responsibility for administering the organisation, is not something which ministers should tinker with. The board has an obligation under its act. The board is appointed. The board has to clear with the minister its corporate plan and its strategic plan for addressing the issues that it has responsibility for, and it does that. But it is for the organisation to deliver and not for ministers to politically interfere and push the CSIRO down the course of picking winners or direct how the CSIRO should deploy its funding in order to meet the needs of sectional interests. That has to be quite categoric. That has to be quite clear between all of us.

It is for those reasons that I, as minister at the time, resisted pressures placed on me, some of which emanated in this chamber, to interfere with the CSIRO and direct its research effort in a way in which particular honourable senators would want me to do. Having said that, the other factor here too was that the CSIRO itself was undertaking a major review of its operations.

As I said earlier, the CSIRO is sensitive to public criticism and is aware of the weighty responsibility it has under its act. It is an organisation that is conscientious about pursuing its goals. The board had introduced a major review of its management structure and even if I were tempted to intervene, as the pressure was pushing me to do, it was prudent not to for the very reason that the board was itself addressing issues that it felt important.

That has been quite a major review by the CSIRO. The former director of the CSIRO has to take a lot of credit for the way in which that review was conducted and for the extensive public consultations and intra‐organisational consultations he undertook so that the outcome of the review was effective from the point of view that it did the job that was required and it did not forsake honest scrutiny for internal peace. It addressed the real questions head on.

Also, the outcome, once formed in the mind of the reviewing body, was consulted through the organisation in a way in which the members of that organisation felt part of it, owned it and were able to apply themselves to the new direction the organisation had adopted. The government response to this Senate committee report shows, in relation to many of the recommendations, that it acknowledges that the CSIRO restructuring has been quite considerable and very effective.

The second ground is that the CSIRO was doing the job, has now done the job and the government of which—that is, the senators who were then in opposition and were criticising me—does endorse the restructuring self-imposed by the board on the CSIRO with the consensus and support of workers and stakeholders in that organisation.

What also has to be said about this is that there is a tendency to think of a body like the CSIRO in a static way. When the CSIRO was first created, the major industries in this country were pastoral, agricultural and mining and the CSIRO in its early days achieved part of its international reputation by breakthrough research in those particular areas, meeting the needs of those industry sectors. The science that it did in the manufacturing sector added to its reputation, but its main preoccupation was in the other areas.

Science is not a static thing. The frontiers of science are exploding exponentially all the time. It is refining itself and becoming more detailed. Areas of science which are now a gleam in the eye of some scientists, or do not even exist in fact, will in five or 10 years time be areas of public demand and of great importance, such is the exploding nature of knowledge in the science area, and the CSIRO as a body has to keep abreast of that.

So, under its mandate, this is an organisation under considerable strain at all times to meet its obligations to the community. It has to be said that it is an organisation which would have it no other way. The rise of information technology, the rise of genetic research and the rise of a whole range of new areas of science and research in light metals and across areas of environmental technology are specialities that now are obvious to us which were not on the map 10 years ago.

So it is not surprising, given those strains and those pressures, the CSIRO is in a constant state of reorganising its priorities and focusing the effort where it will do most good in the national interest. In constantly restructuring itself to deliver that outcome, it is not surprising from time to time that when sectional interests divine particular needs may not be serviced as they choose to require them to be there will be outcries.

I ask that the Senate remind itself always that this is an organisation with an incredible mandate which is expanding all the time. It does behove governments to give it the support necessary to address those issues, and that includes rural research. It does behove the government to do that, but it also behoves governments to support it in being at the leading edge in the frontiers of the new areas of research that are developing. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I too want to join with Senator Cook in drawing attention to the report CSIRO: The case for revitalisation . We had in Senator Cook a very good minister. Since the change of government we have seen a reduction in the funding to the CSIRO. Out of this report I wanted to look specifically at rural research, particularly at Chiswick, Arding and Longford. These are properties up near Armidale.

BREAK.PARA: In the report it was recommended that these not be sold. However, the government and the CSIRO have decided to do differently. There were 80 staff employed in that area. It is now down to 35. We actually had the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr McGauran) up there last week saying this was wonderful, they were saving it, but a number of those projects do not have a particularly long lifespan. I am not sure what happens to Armidale's Chiswick after that is completed.

This is a rural community in the middle of the wool growing area and in the middle of the beef industry. It is close to grain production and a wide range of other agricultural pursuits. Yet we have the government saying that reducing the scientific staff from 80 to 35 is a plus for CSIRO. It is certainly not a plus for Armidale. It is certainly not a plus for those who have been involved with CRCs and every other sort of research that goes on in the area.

There is a synergy between CSIRO, the CRCs and the University of New England. I would have thought the government would have been looking at ways to maximise that synergy to provide for the employment of people in rural areas because CSIRO has such a significant contribution to make in the area of rural production and rural research, but that does not appear to be the case. It is becoming easier and easier these days to actually site institutions in rural areas because with the advent of improved technology, improved telecommunications and the like, communication is not a problem and the transfer of information and material between the various institutions of the organisation also is not a problem.

In relation to this reduction and sale, I am concerned that a lot of the money that has gone into the development of these sites has actually come from the wool growers through Wool International. I wonder legally just how many of those sites are owned fully by CSIRO and how many might well be said to be owned by the wool industry. They are very concerned about that.

The newspapers of the area in the last number of weeks have certainly been raising the concerns, the concerns of the mayor of Armidale and the mayor of Dumeresq. They have every right to be concerned because they are seeing the bleeding by this government of the intellectual base from their area. There is nowhere else in the region that scientists can hope to get a job, that the 40-odd who have been given redundancies can hope to get similar employment. The university may be able to take one or two. The state government's vet labs may be able to take one or two, but that leaves the rest. What are they going to do? We are going to see a continuation of the brain drain from rural Australia, in this case rural New South Wales.

What it costs people to sell their houses in Armidale is nowhere near the replacement cost of housing the people will have to buy. If they move to get a job in science, they are likely to move to a capital city. So they are going to be discriminated against and have hardship placed upon them in the purely physical sense of having to sell their house for a value that is less than an equivalent house in a capital city or a much larger centre that they will be forced to move to.

We also have to ask: what is going to happen to the schools and to the communities? When you lose 45 people, if they move from the area, you lose 45 families. There is the multiplier effect in employment, spending and the schools and institutions in the community. Presumably a number of the spouses also have employment in the area, so what is going to be the impact?

As I said, we are seeing this government cause a brain drain from the rural areas of Australia, especially New South Wales in this case, to the cities. This is the government that is supposed to be concerned about rural areas. From talking to the people in the region—many of them are National Party voters and card‐carrying members of the National Party—I have found that they are very angry about this because they feel that they have been let down by their party and by their government. That is something that people need to be very conscious of.

I repeat: these are areas that have been doing research that is of high value to the farming communities and the grazing communities. The amount of money that they are receiving from the private sector, from external sources, is very high. It is above the amount set by the board of CSIRO. They have done everything they can to provide a high level scientific research service. It is a research service that has operated in very close cooperation with the industry. A number of extremely good projects are being run. It would be very sad to see these not continue or not receive extensions to their time when the current funding levels are completed.

It behoves the government to look very carefully at this issue, but they are not going to. Whilst they stood up on budget night and said that they had increased funding to the CSIRO, when you actually took into account the efficiency dividends across the board and several other cuts, they are receiving less money.

This government is determined to reduce the scientific work that is carried out in this country. It is not only going to lead to a brain drain out of the rural areas but it is also going to lead to a brain drain as scientists will have to leave Australia to find gainful work and continue to undertake their extremely important research work. I urge the government to think very carefully about this. This appears to be just another example of the attitude that farmers are beginning to think this government has of not caring about the future of agriculture in this country. They think they are more interested in other pursuits and other forms of income revenue and sources of revenue.

I leave it there by repeating that this is of major concern to the people in the Armidale and New England regions of New South Wales, as I am sure it is to the farming communities and the woolgrowers and the beef producers right across this country.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —This report of the Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts References Committee entitled Telstra: To sell or not to sell? contains a huge number of issues that go not only to the issue of the partial privatisation of Telstra but really explore where our telecommunications industry is going in Australia. As a member of the committee that conducted the inquiry during the winter recess it was interesting to see the behaviour of the government members on that committee and the way in which they complained bitterly about having to go through the exercise of conducting the inquiry. Whilst I do not want to dwell on that point, I would like to make the comment that that leads to a very clear situation of the government having something to hide on this issue. The basis of it is as follows.

SPEECH.PARA: The association between the partial sale of Telstra and the environment was motivated out of a cute political trick. It was a cute political trick engineered by the government with no policy substance but done in a way to try to link the numbers in this place to pursuing a piece of legislation that solved some of their financial problems in their overcommitments in the election campaign to funding $7 billion of an alleged deficit and so forth. The fact that that has not worked has been exposed thoroughly through the subsequent experience we have had with the exploration of the Natural Heritage Trust of Australia Bill. The relevant legislation committee heard that the environment groups in Australia are not convinced that it is a necessity to partially sell Telstra to fund the environment program.

BREAK.PARA: Those environment groups have said that the linking of the sale of Telstra in funding those crucial environment programs sets a very dangerous precedent. It sets a precedent on the basis that this government proposes to sell public assets to fund recurrent expenditure programs. The programs listed in the natural heritage trust bill are recurrent expenditure programs. This flies in the face of the comments made in the coalition's policy document that the revenue created from the sale of public assets, specifically Telstra in this case, will go towards capital expenditure only and capital programs.

This serves as evidence of the motivation of the coalition to linking the sale of Telstra with the environment program. It is a political con. They know it has not worked. The coalition has prepared its minority report and are saying, `We have the evidence to show that there is some merit in the partial privatisation of Telstra.'

This is where this report is so crucial and important to this debate. It exposes the very point that this government cannot produce evidence. They cannot produce evidence that the partial privatisation of Telstra will benefit the community in this country and the competitive position of Telstra and its development. They cannot produce any evidence that there will be any benefit with respect to the issues that were raised about the future of our telecommunications industry.

In the course of the inquiry, the only groups to really come out in support of the coalition's policy were—lo and behold!—Telstra themselves, the Department of Finance and, of course, the Department of Communications and the Arts. There were certainly other groups that supported the notion of partial privatisation, but their evidence was based on the same flawed evidence put forward by the departments in the period this inquiry was conducted. That evidence was based primarily on a World Bank study, which looked at overseas privatisations and tried to extract specific areas where productivity improved as a result of privatisation as distinct from competition.

This is where they failed to draw any comparison. They could not prove in any way, shape or form that there was a benefit in introducing partial privatisation as opposed to increasing competition in telecommunications. One shambly bit of evidence emerged regarding two companies in Chile during the Pinochet regime, where the figure 1.5 per cent was scrupulously extracted—I am sure—to try to demonstrate that something was there. The bottom line is that there is no empirical evidence to prove that privatisation itself improves the competitiveness, the efficiency or, in fact, the level of services provided to customers with respect to telecommunications.

Opposition to the sale of Telstra is far and wide. The terms of reference were broad enough to bring in many issues. There is no evidence that the revenue return to the government from this privatisation would outweigh the returns that can be gleaned from dividends over a period of time. The record profits of Telstra this year only serve to reinforce that point and further expose the arguments of the government and the departments in that regard.

The impact on regional jobs is massive. A third of those jobs are to go. Many of my senatorial colleagues have spoken previously about the impact of this on jobs. This is where this inquiry has proved very important. It exposed project Mercury. If this inquiry had not occurred, we would not have known about the 24,000 jobs that would go throughout Australia.

Research and development is another crucial area where, through this inquiry and subsequent estimates hearings, we have been able to show that R&D will suffer hugely from the move towards privatisation. It is an area that Telstra, in preparation for privatisation, is paring back and battening down—`removing the fat' in their language. But they are denying Australia the opportunity to expand the telecommunications industry and really look to the future to see what Telstra can provide to the public, the community, through public ownership of that organisation.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —It being 7.20 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert, Sen Paul

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to briefly comment on a matter that was highlighted in our local newspaper in Hobart today. I note that Senator Brown made formal a notice of motion today with respect to the proposed visit of the USS Carl Vinson aircraft carrier to Hobart in a couple of weeks time. We have a situation, created by this minority government in Tasmania, particularly by the Tasmanian Greens, which I believe is working against the best wishes and the best interests of the people of Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: This is not the first visit that the Carl Vinson has made to Hobart; it is the second. In fact, in its last visit I had the pleasure of being invited on board and participating in a reception that was put on by the commander. I also had the pleasure of visiting the
USS Takoma , a nuclear powered submarine, when it had previously visited Hobart.

I want to make the point that some time ago the Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee, particularly my colleague Senator Newman, took part in a report to the Senate on the safety or otherwise of visits to Australia by nuclear powered ships. It was a very comprehensive report. Some hundreds of pages were put together, using all the available information and advice that was given. It virtually has become the bible around Australia in relation to visits of nuclear powered vessels.

In Hobart, the capital of my home state of Tasmania, where there is one of the best harbours in Australia if not the world, an emergency management plan was put in place to deal with any vessel having problems—and I do not ever suspect that they would have problems, but if they did have—and ensuring that the safety of all residents of Hobart, including even those in hospitals, would be catered for.

Prior to the Senate election I was listening to Senator Brown one night—and he was not Senator Brown then but just Bob Brown—giving a bit of a policy speech and talking about what he was going to do. I noted with interest that he was highlighting the fact that, as a senator, he would work for Tasmania, promoting small business and jobs for young people. So far his track record and that of the Tasmanian Greens has been anti-development, anti-everything—and this is just another example of how they work against the interests of the people of Tasmania.

For instance, it is estimated that the visit of the USS Carl Vinson will put something like $10 million into the pockets of the local economy. Just as an example, six local companies will be receiving over $1 million for the aircraft carrier's rubbish removal and ferry services. A Tasmanian company has won a contract to clean and paint the 317 metre carrier. Those two things in themselves are very significant for the Tasmanian work force. We have a very high unemployment rate in Tasmania, and opportunities like this do not come along every day.

We have the ludicrous situation where the Tasmanian Greens and the Labor Party in Tasmania banded together to force the Speaker of the House of Assembly to send a letter to the American President saying, `We don't want you in Hobart' while on the very same day the Premier of Tasmania had to send a letter saying, `We do want you in Hobart.' It really is, as was pointed out in today's editorial in the Mercury, `an absolute debacle'. It is a prime example of what can happen when you have minority governments, particularly where the tail is being wagged by the green movement. It just shows you what can happen and how a state like Tasmania can be disadvantaged.

As I have said, there are positives to this particular visit. This is not the first visit of an American naval vessel. The reason given for personnel liking to come to Tasmania is that the people of Tasmania make them very welcome. I believe that, if a referendum were to be held on whether Tasmanians would like to continue to have visits by American naval vessels, there would be an overwhelming response.

In conclusion, I just wanted to refer to the nuclear debate in Hobart and point to the associated debacle. It has happened before; this is not the first occasion on which we have had these anti-development, anti-everything Greens trying to stop the local businesses receiving some well needed cash. For instance, I note that, when the aircraft carrier arrives, more than $1 million in cash will be taken out by ferry to the people on that aircraft carrier so that they can spend that money in Hobart—which will be to the benefit of the local community.

I note that Senator O'Brien is in the chamber. I do not know whether he supports my views about the visits of the American navy and ships into Hobart. But I am very disappointed to see that the state Labor Party and the Greens joined together to create this situation where we have conflicting advice going to the American government. I just think, in the interests of Tasmania and small business in the area, it is a pretty poor effort that has been put up, particularly by the Tasmanian Greens.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop, Sen Mark

TALK.START.PARA: —This week the Economist Intelligence Unit released a report entitled, Australia's Foreign Investment Challenge: The Harsh Realities . It outlined the views of managers from over 50 multi-national corporations on Australia as an investment destination. The report gained significant press in the national media. According to the report, Australia accounts for only one to two per cent of global sales, therefore we are not a high priority at the boardroom tables of multi-national corporations. One manager said that, since Australia only has one per cent of their sales market, we `get about one per cent of the board's attention'.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia will never be a country which has a large domestic market. However, our location provides us with the opportunity to be a production and support site supplying the fast‐growing Asian region. The key point to come out of the report is that there is a real perception amongst managers that Australia lacks a coherent and consistent industry policy, both at the macro‐economic level and for many specific industries. The managers in the report complain that it is not obvious who is in charge of industry policy in Canberra. They say that `existing policies change too often'. I would like to quote one manager's experience. He said:
We've spent four years building up exports from Australia and headquarters was beginning to accept that we were a viable sourcing site.

But in the government's scramble to cover its deficit it cuts the tariff concession order so we now pay a 3% import tax on materials that are not even produced in Australia. Policy changes like these seem to come out of the blue with no clear direction or aim and seem to totally ignore industry.

The hesitance of many multi‐nationals to invest in Australia because of a perceived lack of industry policy is concerning in light pf the report's revelation that many of the world's leading multi‐national corporations have already decided to put their next world‐scale plant in Asia—but are yet to decide where. This is a great opportunity and we must give them a reason to choose Australia.

The government's irrational fear of industry policy should not prevent Australia from missing out on the huge export revenues that will flow from multi‐national corporations locating their regional manufacturing plants in this country. These plants will export to the entire region. The average multi‐national plans on more than tripling its sales in this region. This means huge export revenues for the countries where they choose to establish their headquarters. And the establishment of value‐adding, export‐orientated manufactured plants in Australia will create real jobs and contribute significantly to lifting our standard of living.

Strategic industry policy was pursued successfully by the previous Labor government. According to the report, 11 per cent of the firms interviewed were involved in the Button car plan, which lifted automotive exports from under $400 million in 1984 to $1.5 billion in 1995. Sixteen per cent were involved in factor F, which increased pharmaceutical industry exports to their current levels of $1.4 billion per year. Twenty seven per cent were involved in the successful partnership for development scheme. Other industry policies include the book bounty, which increased book exports by 200 per cent; and the shipbuilding bounty, which saw production rise nearly 200 per cent and exports grow by 150 per cent.

The report's statement that the biggest magnet for multi-national corporations is a broad, cohesive industry policy should come as no surprise. Report after report, all by prominent organisations such as the World Bank, have said that a key reason for East Asia's stunning growth over the past three decades has been the effective industry policy of countries in that region.

It is clear from the report that we are facing strong competition from Asian countries when multinational corporations consider where to locate. As the report says, `The Asian countries Australia competes against are all driven by industry policy and, if you want to win investment away from them, you have to focus on having a coherent industry policy.' Seventy‐four per cent of managers feel Australia does not have a clear industry policy. Seventy‐nine per cent believe we do not have a consistent industry policy and 72 per cent believe industry policy is not consistent across federal ministries.

One senior manager explained that he had worked in a number of countries, but he found Australia's system of developing industry policy the strangest of all. He outlined how the industry department consulted industry whilst Treasury preferred to look at academic studies of economic studies of efficiency. He said managers did not know which department to believe, and described it as `a system guaranteed to create confusion'.

It is clear from this report that there needs to be a debate in this country regarding the development of an effective industry policy. We should look at our competitors in the region and develop policies which will ensure that we meet the challenge of competition. The current idea of simply opening a textbook and following it to the letter does not work. The report specifically criticised `frequent government statements that they are not in the business of picking winners or providing "corporate welfare"'. Rather, it must be recognised that the government has a responsibility to create truly level playing fields. We must have the same concept of the level playing field as our Asian neighbours do. This means public policy directed towards assistance to high value, high yield, expanding export‐oriented manufacturing industries.

The government has a responsibility to nurture these key industries and a responsibility to ensure good economic policy that delivers results is followed, not some blind ideological pursuit. This report is a deafening warning bell to the government: unless you develop a strong industry policy, Australia will not attract the foreign investment which is so integral to the growth in our economy and, over time, the living standards of all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak this evening on a matter which recently came to my attention. It involves coverage on Media Watch by Stuart Littlemore of a program which was put to air on 1 September this year by 60 Minutes . That program involved a story involving the Christian Brothers. What has come to my attention has caused me a great deal of concern, to say the least. In fact, Stuart Littlemore described this whole affair as `breathtakingly dishonest'. What happened was that Geoff McMullan interviewed Brother Tony Shanahan, the provincial head of the Christian Brothers. During the course of the interview, he asked him:

SPEECH.PARA: We're talking about possible murder within the Christian Brothers.
The answer that Brother Shanahan gave was as follows:
The evidence on the information I have is that yes, the allegation was made, but there is nothing, there's nothing, there is no other evidence to support that.

That is what Brother Shanahan said but that is not what 60 Minutes put on air as being the reply to the question. What in fact 60 Minutes did was it showed Brother Shanahan being at a loss for words, frowning and having to grasp a glass of water and take a drink from the glass. That was not his response to the question. In fact, what it gave the viewer was an impression of some sort of guilt, some sort of concern by Brother Shanahan, some sort of amazement or surprise. Indeed, that was not the answer that Brother Shanahan gave. That was not his response. The wrong segment was put in as the answer and passed off dishonestly as his response to that question. Of course, that misled any viewer who would be looking at that.

It came to my attention that this had, in fact, been looked at by Media Watch and I note that Stuart Littlemore said that Peter Meakin, Channel Nine's current affairs boss, declined an interview with Media Watch in relation to this. I think it is quite a scandalous piece of journalism. Stuart Littlemore said that it really was not the interviewer's fault, as such. It was not Geoff McMullan's fault. It was, in fact, the fault of the producer who put the program together, and I take his point. I find this piece of journalism absolutely scandalous. I have a tape of Media Watch for any of those senators who would like to watch it. I think that once you see it, and see how the deception occurred, you too would be most concerned.
I also wish to refer to the question of these so‐called unexplained deaths that were raised by the program. Brother Shanahan mentioned, in a letter dated 4 September 1996:

It is perhaps significant that no other mainstream media have seen fit to pick up these stories over the last few years. They refer to four students who are buried at Bindoon and one who died in a fall at Tardun in 1949. Two of the students buried at Bindoon died in road accidents after they had left Bindoon and were brought back there for burial. The other two died in accidents, one falling under the wheel of a cart on the farm, and the other striking his head on the stairs as he fell from a balustrade down which he was sliding. The lad at Tardun was a sleep walker and was discovered one morning below an open verandah on the first floor where he slept, with other students. It is presumed that he walked over the edge of the balcony in his sleep and was killed in the fall.

In none of these cases did the examining doctor who signed the death certificate see fit to ask for an inquest. I am aware of no evidence which would cause us to re‐examine the circumstances of these deaths. I am aware of no‐one offering any eye witness testimony to contradict what we know of their deaths.

That is an account of what took place, but 60 Minutes put it in the context of a possible murder within the Christian Brothers. That is absolutely disgraceful because there is the explanation and, indeed, Brother Shanahan's answer that he gave to 60 Minutes said that there was no evidence to show that there was any foul play afoot.

I note that there was a letter written to the director of 60 Minutes by Professor Ivan Kennedy, who is a professor in agricultural and environmental chemistry from the University of Sydney. He is an old boy from Clontarf Boys Town. He said:

. . . I find it impossible to relate what I saw in your program last Sunday night with my very positive experiences at Clontarf for several years in the first half of the 1950s. My clear recollection is of a well run and caring enterprise of which the Christian Brothers have every right to be proud and with many achievements of which most of the boys certainly were.
Professor Kennedy goes on to mention:
. . . I have attended Perth on several occasions to attend Old Boys' reunions.
Those old boys included a VC winner, a number of university graduates, business managers, senior civil servants and a host of others who have made a go of their lives.

That stands as testament to the fine work that the Christian Brothers have done in this country. I know that in this Senate there are several senators who are a product of their education and hard work. I find it despicable that we have this sort of journalism which tries to bring down such a fine institution and fine body of men.

I raise this tonight in the wake of the beatification of Edmund Rice, who is the founder of the Christian Brothers. He was beatified on Sunday, 6 October this year in Rome. I think it is fitting that he was beatified as the founder of the Christian Brothers. I will be talking on that matter on another day in this Senate. I certainly will be taking this matter of 60 Minutes up with the minister concerned. I will be bringing it to the attention of the producers of 60 Minutes because I think this is a matter which should not go without comment. I find it thoroughly despicable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this evening to speak in relation to an enterprise agreement which has been recently ratified by the enterprise commissioner in the state of Tasmania. The enterprise agreement relates to a number of businesses and is known as the Margate bakery enterprise agreement. This is one of a number of agreements which have been approved under the Tasmanian industrial relations system which operate to reduce the conditions and wages of employment of future employees, not those employees who are party to the making of the agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: In my view, there is a questionable morality operating with this sort of agreement. It has received some debate in the consideration of the report of the Senate Economics References Committee on the workplace relations bill which will no doubt be dealt with elsewhere.

I make the point that with agreements such as this, future employees have no recourse at law in relation to the signing away of their rights to wages and conditions otherwise prescribed by awards by employees who are not so affected. However, in this case, there was a very grave question raised with regard to the fairness of the bargaining process which took place with the making of this particular enterprise agreement which applies to three baking establishments in southern Tasmania.

The agreement was drafted by a representative of the employer who was employed by the Tasmanian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, and presented to the employees. Meetings were held at which a representative of that employer organisation attended and was the only source of information for the employees as to their rights and the impact of that agreement upon them. Subsequent to that meeting and during the process of a ballot of employees which was properly conducted in other respects, a representative of the Australian Liquor, Hospitality and Miscellaneous Workers Union sought to have distributed to employees a one page document which set out some of their rights and inviting them, if they had any questions on any matters, to contact the union.

It is uncontested—and this matter has been raised before the enterprise commissioner and in correspondence that I am in possession of—that a representative of the employer advised the employee who received those documents to tear them up and throw them in the bin. The employer was concerned on the one hand to have the employer's view made clear to the employees but when there was an alternative view, albeit a one page document which was prepared by an official of the union, that was not to be seen by the employees. I suggest that in those circumstances there is a very questionable practice of fairness being followed by the employer.

Following that process, a young man employed in the business wrote to the enterprise commissioner in the context of a hearing which was being held, as I understand it, in a home of either the employer or someone connected with the employer. That is where the hearing was held. This young man wrote to the enterprise commissioner setting out his concerns and sent a copy to the Tasmanian Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Cornish.

In that letter the young man says a number of things. Because of my limited time I will seek to table a copy of the union notice I referred to, a copy of the letter of Mr Christopher Gard, a copy of correspondence from Mr Terry Edwards, the manager of industrial services for the Tasmania Chamber of Commerce and Industry Limited, and a copy of a letter which is from a Mrs Elaine Lincolne, the mother of the young man, Mr Christopher Gard. I seek leave to table those.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to that correspondence, it is clear—and the young man makes quite a number of points—that he is unhappy with the process and the agreement. I think he is quite brave to have done what he did. He says, amongst other things:

SPEECH.PARA: The whole agreement revolves around changes that reduce wages and conditions of employment. This represents an insecure future for me because if the agreement succeeds I will probably lose my job so that some-one on a lesser rate of pay can be employed. If this is in fact not the case I don't see any reason for bringing it in in the first place. The other problem that it will cause is people doing the same work for different rates of pay and this will cause problems in the workplace because it is unfair.

I also have some concerns about the Employer having knowledge of a new proposed Baking Industry Award which I believe is nearing completion. I have been informed the majority of the new proposals have been agreed to by the Unions and the TCCI—
which is the employer organisation I referred to—
on a `without prejudice' basis and discussions to resolve the few outstanding clauses has been listed for the first week in October.

We should have been told about this so that we could make real comparisons that related to the situation for the next 2 years and not on an award that will most likely be superseded in the near future.

Also when a representative from the Union attempted to hand over some documentation to employees that would inform them of this new proposed award it was destroyed and not passed on. As a union member I was never given the opportunity to involve my representative in any way.
He finishes the letter by saying:
I am almost 20 years of age and have worked in the Bakery for 15 months—my first real job and I like it. I do not want to lose my job but I feel I should have an opportunity to voice my concerns.

Subsequent to that, because a copy was sent to the minister, the minister contacted an officer of his department, Mr Edwards of the Tasmanian Chamber of Commerce and Industry. Mr Edwards responded questioning the process of writing to the minister in the circumstances and questioning the genuineness of the letter. He said in the letter, amongst other things:

Minister I believe . . . that Mr Gard's letter is something of a beat up and given the circulation list is probably more designed for its political impact rather than being the genuinely held concerns of an employee.
As I said, there is a great deal of information to deal with here.

In a response to that, the letter from the young man's mother, which I have tabled, says, amongst other things, that the letter had been sent to the minister because he was the minister responsible for the act under which the agreement was being reached. In reference to that letter—and I strongly urge senators to have a close look at these papers—it is clear that the young man's mother, Mrs Lincolne, is not an opponent to enterprise bargaining but rather an opponent to the unfair way in which this agreement was reached. It is a very considered letter and I strongly urge senators to have regard to it. This is, in my opinion, a very unfortunate set of circumstances.

In closing, I cannot help taking advantage of the opportunity to refer to some comments that were made during question time by Senator Alston. In a somewhat gratuitous comment he referred to failed union officials on this side of the Senate. It would be equally improper of me to be referring to members of the legal profession who sit on the other side of the chamber as failed members of the legal profession because they were in this chamber. It is rather that they are serving the nation at a higher level—not one which ought to be denigrated in this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 30 July 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has Airservices Australia called for expressions of interest in the provision of fire vehicles for major civil airports.
(2) Which company or companies supplied the fire vehicles currently in use at these airports and why are they being replaced.

(3) Is it the practice of the Government to seek to maximise local content in such contracts; if so, has that policy position been conveyed to the Board of Airservices Australia and has the Board advised Airservices Australia management accordingly.
(4) When will the tender be let for the supply of these vehicles.

(6) Did the Invitation to Register document specify that the vehicles should be of proven design, already in operation and require only minimum design changes based on functional requirements to suit Australian conditions.
